news uk-news amazing-lottery-winner-finds-out-"Care worker Vicky Channing was left crying tears of joy after winning £, playing Peopleaposs Postcode Lottery. The -year-old, from Broad Oak, Kent, scooped the prize after her postcode, TN TN, was announced as a winner. But it wasnapost until she received a Zoom call from People’s Postcode Lottery ambassador Matt Johnson that she learned how much she had won.When Matt revealed the cheque, tearful Vicky said: “Oh my God! Are you serious  Thank you so much, that’s amazing!” Vicky plans on treating her two children, who are six and eight years old, to a trip to Disneyland when restrictions allow.And she also has plans to splash out on an extravagant purchase for her home, which she shares with her husband.  She added: “We wanted to get a hot tub. I was going to have to work extra nights and days to save up for it and now I can actually get it, I’m so excited!“ One of the reasons Vicky plays People’s Postcode Lottery is because of the support going to good causes. She went on: “I always like to give a bit to charity, and I can’t always do all of them, so I thought this is the perfect one to do because it covers quite a few. And obviously there is always a chance of winning so that is an extra bonus on top!” People’s Postcode Lottery costs £ a month to play and there are guaranteed winners every day. People play with their chosen postcode and are automatically entered into all draws.People’s Postcode Lottery ambassador, Matt Johnson, said: “I’m over the moon for Vicky! A big congratulations, I hope she celebrates today and enjoys spending the cash.” A huge % of ticket sales goes directly to good causes and players of People’s Postcode Lottery have helped raise over £ million for good causes across Britain and internationally since . This draw was promoted on behalf of Unicef UK, which has received over £.million in funding thanks to players. FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorMore OnBettingLottery

title: corrupt cop who helped gangsters
story: NewsCorrupt cop who helped gangsters steal from rivals in Line of Duty-style plot jailedFormer PC Kash Mahmood, , was described as "audacious, corrupt and criminal" after confiscating hundreds of thousands of pounds from traffickers during fake stopsmirrorShareCommentsByTom Pettor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsMahmoodwas pictured with some of his co-defendants in Dubai" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA bent cop who helped gangsters steal from their rivals in a Line of Duty-style corruption plot has been jailed for eight years. Kash Mahmood, , was described as audacious, corrupt and criminal after confiscating hundreds of thousands of pounds from traffickers during fake stops. Sentencing him at Southwark Crown Court on Thursday Judge David Tomlinson said Mahmood abused his position of power, trust and responsibility. Mahmood remained impassive as he was led to the cells in blue shirt and black facemask. Judge Tomlinson said he would have known he was putting iniduals in danger by leaving those he stole from vulnerable to reprisals from their underworld bosses.Got a story  Email webnews@mirror. Addressing the former PC and his co-defendants, the judge said: “aposIt must have been plain to all of you that these couriers were being put in harmaposs way.” Mahmood was allegedly tipped off about who to target by the Dubai based mastermind of the organised crime group who was using an encrypted EncroChat phone. Mujtaba Neazmand, an Afghani national, left the UK in  after being made the subject of a proceeds of crime order and is believed to be there now.  Detectives would not be drawn on whether he is wanted in the UK. Hundreds of top and middle level organised crime figures have been arrested after the EncroChat phone network was hacked by European law enforcement last year. The court heard how Mahmood had become the first in his family to go to university, after avoiding the pull of criminal gangs while growing up in east London.  He had been stabbed as a teenager for refusing to get involved in crime, his barrister Bill Emlyn Jones said. But after ten years as a successful officer with five commendations his “background caught up with him”, the court heard. Mr Emlyn Jones said: “He thought he had escaped it, but it pulled him back in.”  Mahmood jetted off to Dubai where he was pictured with his co-defendants and splashed out on a £, Rolex watch. The court heard he was a longtime associate of gangster twins Shabaz Khan, , and Shazad Khan, , and their brother Moshin Khan, . He misused police computers to check what intelligence was held about the brothers and Neazmand. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Mahmood, of Harlow, Essex, admitted conspiracy to acquire criminal property and misconduct in a public office at an earlier hearing. He was kicked out of the Met last year after a disciplinary  found he had driven a police car while his associate posed as a police officer to seize cash which was due to be laundered or was payment for drugs. Mohsin Khan was sentenced to  years for conspiracy to supply class A drugs, conspiracy to transfer criminal property and conspiracy to acquire criminal property.  Shabaz Khan was jailed for  years for conspiracy to supply class A drugs, conspiracy to transfer criminal property, conspiracy to acquire criminal property and possession of a controlled drug of class B with intent to supply. Shazad Khan was sentenced to  years and five years and four months in jail respectively for conspiracy to supply class A drugs, conspiracy to transfer criminal property and conspiracy to acquire criminal property. Ioan Gherghel, who dressed as an officer while accompanying his friend Mahmood on the raids, was jailed six years for conspiracy to acquire criminal property. Moshin Khanaposs ex-partner Maria Shah, , admitted supplying class A drugs and conspiracy to acquire criminal property and was sentenced to five years and four months. Scotland Yardaposs Deputy Assistant Commissioner Bas Javid, Directorate of Professionalism, said: “Mahmood may have been a police constable in name, but he was nothing more than a criminal who abused his position to look after the interests of organised crime.” Steve Noonan, of the Independent Office of Police Conduct, said: “This officer’s behaviour was audacious, corrupt and criminal. His actions were a complete betrayal of public trust and confidence and have no place in policing.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMohsin KhanScotland YardCourt caseCrown courtPolice carCrimeTeenagersTwinsKne crime

title: gp surgeries must offer face
story: NewsAll GP surgeries must offer face-to-face appointments from Monday with receptions openA letter sent out to GPs on Thursday has said the use of telephone and online consultations can remain where patients benefit from them, but physical appointments must also be available from May mirrorShareCommentsByTess de la MareJonathan ColesReporter:,  MAY NewsCurrently around half of consultations in general practice are being delivered face to face " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAll GP practices in England must offer face-to-face appointments, the NHS has said - bringing an end to the apostotal triageapos system. The process - which saw patients remotely screened - was put in place during the pandemic to minimise the spread of infection. There had been talk of the system being adopted even after le ed to normal - a move criticised by some medical groups. A letter sent out to GPs on Thursday has now said the use of telephone and online consultations can remain where patients benefit from them, but physical appointments must also be available from May . All practice reception desks must also be open to patients in a Covid-safe manner so those who do not have easy access to phones or the internet are not disadvantaged when accessing care, it added. Do you have a view on this story  Email webnews@mirror.  Currently around half of consultations in general practice are being delivered face to face. Before the pandemic, some  per cent of appointments were face-to-face and  per cent were phone, video or online, but this switched to around  per cent face-to-face and  per cent remote at the height of the crisis. Total triage, introduced in March , saw patients being remotely screened and directed to the most appropriate health service for their problems. GP appointments were also conducted by telephone, video or online unless it was clinically necessary for a consultation to take place in person. In the joint letter from Dr Nikki Kanani, medical director for primary care at NHS England and director of primary care Ed Waller, doctors were told patientsapos preferences must be respected. Patients and clinicians have a choice of consultation mode, they said. They added: Patientsapos input into this choice should be sought and practices should respect preferences for face-to-face care unless there are good clinical reasons to the contrary. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here.Dr Kanani and Mr Waller cited the presence of Covid- symptoms as an example of a reason to refuse a face-to-face appointment.Patients should be treated consistently regardless of mode of access, they said.Ideally, a patient attending the practice reception should be triaged on the same basis as they would be via phone or via an online consultation system. Dr Kanani and Mr Waller added that to ensure receptions can open safely, patients might be asked to queue outside. The letter to GPs comes just two days after a report by the Royal College of General Practitionersheavily criticised plans to embed total triage into general practice post-pandemic. The report noted that complex conditions or those of a sensitive nature where a GP might need to pick up on non-verbal queues such as signs of anxiety or indicators of substance abuse can be easily missed remotely. Professor Martin Marshall, chairman of the RCGP, welcomed the news that the option of in-person services should be available to everyone. He said: This is good news and is what patients and GPs want to see. It removes ambiguity and we are particularly pleased that our calls for shared decision-making between GP and patient on the most appropriate method of consultation have been heard. We now have a flexible approach decided upon by clinicians and their patients.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnCoronavirus

title: hundreds travellers descend tiny cotswold
story: NewsHundreds of travellers descend on tiny Cotswold town for -year-old horse festivalThe Stow Horse Fair has ed to Stow-on-the-Wold in Gloucestershire today after being cancelled twice last year due to the pandemic, with travellers from across the country attending the eventmirrorShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  MAY NewsThe biannual Stow Horse Fair has ed to Stow-on-the-Wold for the first time in over a year " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Hundreds of travellers descended on a tiny Cotswold town to enjoy a biannual horse festival as coronavirus restrictions ease across the country.The famous Stow Horse Fair has ed to Stow-on-the-Wold in Gloucestershire today after being cancelled twice last year due to the pandemic. Romany caravans arrived in the town this morning and sold a range of items, including catapults and chickens, to festival visitors, reports say. Equine enthusiasts were in paradise as horses were paraded through the festival and sold. One man was even pictured racing a pony and trap through the muddy field. Festival attendees wore wellies and anoraks as they braved the wet conditions, with some even going barefoot. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here. Council officials and police allowed the event to go ahead due to the aposextremely low Covid infection ratesapos, The Sun reports. A Gloucestershire County Council spokesman told GloucestershireLive said: “Having reviewed the organiser’s risk assessments we reached a collective view that adequate Covid- prevention arrangements were being proposed.“Covid Regulations can only be used to legally stop an event going aheadthere is deemed to be a signicant and imminent risk to public health and the use of the legislation would be a proportionate step to take.  Based on the information provided by the organisers and extremely low infection rates there is insufficient evidence to warrant action under the regulations. “Officers from Cotswold District Council and the Police, supported by Covid support officers, will be on site throughout the event to monitor compliance. Testing will also be available in the area.” The Fair dates back almost five hundred years and originally began as a sheep fair for the Cotswold wool trade. However, over time it started selling other animals and it is now a key event in the traveller communityaposs calendar, drawing in visitors from around the country.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnHorses

title: i hand reared fox cub
story: NewsI hand-reared a fox cub who thinks Im mum - it lives in bathroom and cuddles my poodleEXCLUSIVE: Belinda Rose took in the baby fox after it was brought into her vets and mistaken for an abandoned puppy and now keeps him in her downstairs bathroom which she has covered in tree branches and leavesmirrorShareCommentsByEmma Dunn:,  MAY NewsBelinda Rose with the adorable cub" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA woman has hand-reared a fox cub who thinks she’s its mum - and it lives in her downstairs bathroom and cuddles up to her poodle. Belinda Rose, , took in the baby fox after it was brought into her vets and mistaken for an abandoned puppy. Belinda took him home to nurse him back to health and now keeps him in her downstairs bathroom which she has covered in tree branches and leaves. The fox - who she has not named so she doesn’t get attached - was so small it weighed g but after five weeks in Belinda’s home, in Newmarket, Suffolk, he has grown to .kg and has become more fox-like. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  Belinda has now given the fox cub to a rescue centre - which has other baby foxes for them to continue to recuperate before they are let back into the wild. Belinda, a vet, said: “He was so tiny when I got him. His eyes were closed and he was just a ball of fur so he did look like a puppy. “Every day he has grown and he loves to still snuggle up for a cuddle.  “I’ve had to resist naming him so I don’t get too attached and want to keep him.” Belinda was on a night sht when the cub was brought into her vets. She realised it wasn’t a puppy as initially thought, but in fact a tiny abandoned baby fox and gave it powdered milk.  Realising it needed proper care, Belinda brought the fox to her home and made it comfortable in her downstairs bathroom. “I covered it in leaves and trees,” she said. The baby fox soon started to grow and now eats a diet of meat and dog biscuits.  “He is adorable,” Belinda said. “But he has always had an attitude. “Once I lost him for seven hours and he had crawled behind a bathroom .  “When I found him he came straight for a cuddle.” He is now lapping up milk and eating for himself and gets on well with Belinda’s rescue poodle, Arthur. “They snuggle up next to each other all the time,” she said. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  “Now the fox is bigger, they will play together too.” The fox had been with Belinda for five weeks and has just left her to join a group of other foxes his age to then be released back into the wild in three to four months. “I’m sad to see him go,” Belinda said. “He’s got a special place in my heart.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnFoxesAnimals

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice The worrying Indian coronavirus iant which is rapidly spreading in parts of the UK could already be dominant in London and the North West, according to new data.Cases of the B... iant have more than doubled in the UK - from  to , - in a week as England prepares to ease its lockdown and experts warn the strain will get everywhere in the country. It is certainly possible the Indian iant could overtake the Kent iant and become the countryaposs dominant strain, expert Dr Duncan Robertson told the Mirror.By region in England, London had the highest number of confirmed and suspected cases of the mutant iant -  as of Wednesday, accounting for almost a third of total Covid cases in the capital.The North West was not far behind, with its total of  infections making up a quarter of all confirmed and probable cases of coronavirus in the region, which includes Greater Manchester. Have you tested positive for the Indian coronavirus iant  Email your story to webnews@mirror.  Given the rapid spread of the iant, the Government is facing calls to consider postponing the easing of most Covid restrictions in England in June.Local lockdowns  Prime Minister Boris Johnson has not ruled out local lockdowns being necessary to contain the spread of the virus. Surge testing has been launched in  areas, including Bolton, Formby and parts of London, while increased genomic sequencing and enhanced contact tracing are among other measures being used to prevent the spread of the iant, the Government said. The Government is also considering bringing forward the date for a second dose of vaccine for eligible groups to increase protection.  Data from Public Health Englandshows a rise in cases of the Indian iant from  to , this week in the UK, with the agency saying cases were “rising in the community” and it was assessing the impact and severity of the iant. Three types of the B.. iant, first detected in India, are circulating within the UK, and it is B... that is spreading fast and causing concern. London and the North West have reported the highest number of cases of that strain, which the World Health Organisation has classied as a iant of global concern. In London, the proportion of confirmed and probable cases caused by the B... iant has surged to just under  per cent, while it is . per cent in the North West.  About a quarter of the  total cases in London were people who had travelled. In the North West, where there is widespread community transmission, the proportion of travellers among the  cases was much lower . The number of cases linked to people who had travelled to the UK from India soared in April, figures show. Here is a regional breakdown of the PHE data :London - North West - East - East Midlands - South East - West Midlands - South West - Yorkshire and Humber - North East -  In Bolton, which has one of the highest case rates of the iant in the country, mobile testing units have been deployed and door-to-door PCR Covid testing has been offered to , residents. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. A vaccine bus has been set up to increase uptake among those who are eligible and a rapid response team of  nurses, public health advisers and environmental health officers has been sent in Surge testing has been deployed in Sefton, Merseyside, after cases of the Indian iant were confirmed in the Formby area, with anyone over  who lives, works or studies in the area urged to take a PCR test. Measures have also been brought in where, including in parts of London. In a tweet, Professor Christina Pagel, a mathematician and professor of operational research at University College London, said the iant might already be dominant in London and the North West, based on the PHE figures and using S gene detection as a proxy.  Professor Pagel, a member of Independent Sage, added: I thinkwe just know too little about B... except that itaposs spreading rapidly and the risks are quite high. Dr Robertson, a coronavirus modeller at Loughborough University, told the Mirror that experts cannot be certain where the iant is becoming dominant as it takes time for conclusive sequencing of samples. He added: B... cases appear to be rising in North West England and London and cases have been detected in Bolton, Blackburn with Darwen, Bedford, and Sefton. Some of these cases can be traced back to travellers, but many appear to be due to transmission within the community.  On Thursday, Professor James Naismith, from the University of Oxford, warned the Indian iant should be viewed as a country-wide problem, telling BBC Radio ’s Today programme: “It will get everywhere. We keep learning this lesson, but we know that this will be the case.” It is too soon to predict whether the Indian iant could overtake the Kent strain and become the dominant iant across the whole of the nation. Dr Robertson said: We saw that the Kent iant - B... - became dominant in the new year, and we are seeing signs that some areas are now having cases dominated by B.... It’s finely balanced. The so-called secondary attack rate is very similar between B...and B... .  Basically, we need more time and more data to be more certain. But the high numbers of cases and the high levels of transmissibility mean that it is certainly possible for B... to become dominant – although there may be other iants that emerge that also compete. Dr Robertson said PHE is doing an excellent job collecting and analysing data, and surge testing is helping to gather better data. The Government on Friday said Boris Johnsonaposs June  lockdown roadmap easing – when all legal limits on social contact are due to be lted – was still on track despite the latest figures. Dr Robertson said the Government must be cautious as any risk-taking could increase the likelihood of tougher lockdowns at a national or local level down the road. He added: With all unlocking decisions, it is a balance of risk and reward – the rewards of being able to meet people indoors more easily but the risk of that causing increased transmission and case rates increasing. “We are in a dferent position to late last year. Much of the population is now vaccinated but by no means all. The virus will find the most vulnerable and will causes cases to be found. The question is how many of these cases go on to be hospitalised and die. It is a real risk, and one that only the Government can take. But taking that risk does mean that the potential for reintroduction of more stringent lockdown measures, either at a local or a national level, increases. Speaking on Thursday, Mr Johnson said the Government was “anxious” about the iant and “there is a range of things we could doas he refused to rule out the possibility of local lockdowns. Despite the spread of the Indian iant, Mr Johnson said there was “nothing that dissuades me” from easing England’s lockdown on Monday or the further steps towards normality on June . But he added “there may be things we have to do locally and we will not hesitate to do themthat is the advice we get”. Separate figures compiled by PA show that  per cent of Englandaposs  local areas have seen an increase in coronavirus infection ratesin the seven days to May . Bolton in Greater Manchester has the highest rate, with  new cases in the seven days to May  – the equivalent of . cases per , people. This is up from . in the seven days to May . Erewash in Derbyshire has the second highest rate, up from . to ., with  new cases. Blackburn with Darwen in Lancashire has the third highest, up from . to ., with  new cases. Bedfordand Meltonalso saw signicant week-on-week increases.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMutant CoronavirusCoronavirus

use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThere are fears that the Indian iant of Covid- will hinder the UKaposs pandemic recovery. As experts say vaccines have saved , lives, a surge in cases in Bolton threatens to scupper progress. Scientists and government figures are holding urgent talks amid fears it could delay the end of lockdown rules. Boris Johnson today said he was anxious about the B.. strain, which almost tripled in a week to  UK cases as of May .But there is good news and bad news - and itaposs important to be aware of the facts. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  But how did we get here - and why are authorities so worried  Here are all your key questions answered. . Why are we concerned about the Indian iant  Public Health England believes the iant spreads at least as well as the Kent iant still dominant in the UK. Analysis is ongoing butit turns out to have higher transmissibility then that would give it competitive advantage and it could start to take over. . How has this happened   The original India iant - officially known as B.. - was first detected in October and cases have been imported from abroad. It is now known to be spreading in clusters in some communities. . Is there more than one Indian iant  It has been re-characterised as three dferent subtypes, all with slightly dferent genetic mutations. The UK has seen a sharp increase in one subtype known as B... which now makes up the majority of our cases and appears to be growing faster than others. . Why does it spread easier than previous iants   It contains two key mutations to the outer “spike” protein of the virus that attaches to human cells. Some experts believe it may be overpowering prior immunity from natural infections in some people who had caught earlier iants. . But the good news is... There is no indication yet that it evades the protection offered by current vaccines. This means evenit becomes more prevalent across the UK it should not make most people seriously ill. Widespread vaccinations and natural immunity mean it should not trigger death spikes seen during earlier waves and put hospitals under pressure again. . Why does it put the June  reopening at risk   Increasing Covid- rates with any iant would still kill some unvaccinated people - take-up is lower in ethnic minority communities - or those for whom immune protection has waned. Higher viral prevalence also increases the chances that the virus will mutate again to stop vaccines working as well. . What can the UK do about it  Make use of our world leading genetic sequencing to detect clusters and deploy surge testing. The fact that we are hearing about this increase actually shows the system at work. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. India is now on the travel Red List and restrictions must continue with countries where the iant is prevalent. We are now reliant on our contact tracing systems to stamp out outbreaks. Test and trace has under performed in Britain but is improving as more work is done by trusted local council teams. title: inside covid hotspot bolton cases
story: NewsInside Covid hotspot Bolton as cases surge and locals beg: Give us all the jabEXCLUSIVE: The Mirror paid a visit to Bolton, as a new surge in case makes the Greater Manchester town one of the country’s virus hotspots and residents want the whole town vaccinated - and fastmirrorShareCommentsByAmanda KilleleaBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorMartin Bagot:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsIn Bolton as the town experiences a spike in infections " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeIn Bolton town centre the message from the Government is clear -you have symptoms get a test. But for locals enjoying the sunshine in front of the huge Covid information sign in the town hall square, testing simply isn’t going far enough to tackle the new surge in cases making Bolton one of the country’s virus hotspots. Residents here want the whole town vaccinated - and fast - to prevent another local lockdown like they had last year when most of the rest of the country saw restrictions begin to lt. The infection rate in the town was the second highest in the UK at . cases per , people last week and cases of the Indian iant have risen dramatically in the area. This and the fact infections are also increasing in the under s in the town has led to both Greater Manchester’s mayor Andy Burnham and Bolton North East MP Mark Logan to call for vaccinations for all over s. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  Shopkeeper Mohsin Nazir, , saw his business shut during lockdown and urged everyone to get vaccinated. He said: “I’ve just heard about this new iant that has come from India or somewhere. I think they need to be vaccinating everyone now. I’ve had my vaccine. We just want to get back to some sort of normal le, no more lockdowns, everyone working again.” Carol and Peter Marsden have both been vaccinated but are still very worried about the surge in cases in Bolton.  Retired cook Carol, , says: “They definitely need to start vaccinating the younger people. It is the younger people we see not wearing masks and ignoring social distancing. If people refuse the vaccine they should have to stay at home.” The sudden rise in infections in Bolton is believed to be driven by the B... strain of the virus, often called the Indian iant. It is thought to have been brought into the town by people travelling back and forth from India and Pakistan. There is also a spike in London while an outbreak is Glasgow is also thought to be linked to the iant. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here.Just days before the next lting of lockdown in England is due to take place on Monday, PM Boris Johnson admitted on Thursday he was “anxious” about the new strain.Speaking at a primary school in Ferryhill, Co Durham, the Prime Minister said: “It is a iant of concern, we are anxious about it. At the moment there is a very wide range of scientic opinion about what could happen. “We want to make sure we take all the prudential, cautious steps now that we could take, so there are meetings going on today to consider exactly what we need to do. “There is a range of things we could do, we are ruling nothing out.”  Askedlocal lockdowns were possible, Mr Johnson insisted: “We want to make sure we grip it.” He added: “Obviously there’s surge testing, there’s surge tracing. If we have to do other things, then of course the public would want us to rule nothing out.” But he was confident a spike would not derail Monday’s latest planned unlocking, with Step Three of the Government’s “roadmap” due to be triggered – allowing households to mix indoors, and pubs, restaurants and cafes to serve customers inside.Government scientists were expected to meet on Thursday to discuss the rising coronavirus threat from the Indian iant in Britain. Some members of Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesare believed to be pushing for a delay to the final stage of Boris Johnson’s roadmap out of lockdown set for June . Leading expert Prof James Naismith, of Oxford University, said the iant may spread “way beyond” the local areas where it has been detected. “I think we should view it as a country-wide problem,” he said. “It will get everywhere. We keep learning this lesson, but we know that this will be the case.”  Prof Naismith said he did not believe local restrictions would work to contain the iant, adding: “When we tried locally having dferent restrictions in dferent regions that didn’t really make any dference. “So I don’t think thinking about a localised strategy for containment will really work.” The prospect of a potential future local lockdown is the last thing the people of Bolton want resident Carol adds. “I will be annoyedthey lock us older ones down again when we have stuck by the rules.” Her husband Peter agrees. The retired sheet metal worker, , said: “I heard that people travelled from India. But surely they should have been isolating I don’t understand why international travel hasn’t been banned - this new iant has to have come from somewhere.  “Also I think public transport is a problem in Bolton. When you get on the bus there are a lot of people not wearing masks. The drivers don’t seem to be enforcing it. The older people do, but the younger ones aren’t.” Fishmonger Lee Morris, , who works on Bolton Market, added: “I’m very worried about it - rates in Bolton are now among the highest in the country.I’ve had the vaccine and I feel more confident now that I’ve had it because I work with the public every day. “I think rates in Bolton are high because young people aren’t sticking to the rules - socialising, parties. I do think they should offer younger people the vaccine but that only worksthey take it.I think people are dodging it because they are scared of it. “If they lock us down again I will be devastated. It will have a massive impact on the market.” Students Reia Raichura and Jamiee Patel disagreed that young people were to blame for the spread of the virus - but also had quite dfering views on what to do to stop it.  Jaimee, , had Covid herself last November and lost her grandma to the virus. She has had both vaccines and believes that all young people should be offered it. She said: “I was quite ill and my grandma passed away. I had to isolate for four weeks to see her in her last days. I think everyone should be offered the vaccine now as well as antibody tests.” Her friend Reia Raichura though is still worried about the vaccine - even though cases are rising at their sixth form college. Reia, , said: “We have been sticking to the rules. But I feel it is getting out of hand now. I think they need to think about closing the schools and colleges as well. There have been people testing positive and having to isolate at our sixth form. “I’m still not sure about the vaccine though.” Yesterday the Office for National Statistics announced that seven in ten people in England now test positive for Covid- antibodies, suggesting either vaccination or prior infection. The number was closer to six in ten for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. The European Medicines Agency said on Wednesday that it was “pretty confident” that vaccines currently in use will be effective against the Indian iant. Prof Steven Riley, of Imperial College London, who runs the UK’s biggest Covid- surveillance study, said there was no indication that the iant was increasing hospitalisations. He said: “I think there’s two key things that have got to be kind of evaluated -infections go up, how quickly will they go up  But then after that, are they linked to the hospitalisations  “The top-line Government policy is driven by protecting the NHS, so eveninfection starts to go up, we then need to assess whether that’s bringing a lot of new cases into hospitals, and there’s certainly no sign of that at the moment.” The B... iant is now claiming around , lives a day in India where vaccination rates are much lower.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPoliticsCoronavirusMutant Coronavirus

Owner Judith Brown, who runs the pub The Raglan Arms in the Welsh countryside, with husband William said the couple want to give someone a start in the industry.The Raglan Arms was named one of the top  gastropubs in Wales - and comes with four-bedroom accommodation.It boasts a restaurant seating , a conservatory dining area seating , and a lounge bar seating , as well as an outdoor deck area seating , and a car park with spaces for  cars. title: maggots worms could lunch menus
story: NewsMaggots and worms could be on lunch menus one day for humans to avoid starvationThe Cambridge University team of researchers said future foods to avoid starvationfood from traditional farming dries up include maggots, mealworms, flies and algaemirrorShareCommentsByStephen Beech:,  MAY NewsTourists eat fried insects, including locusts, bamboo worms and dragonfly larvae in China " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeMaggots and worms may be what our grandchildren call dinnerthey are to avoid starvation, suggests a new study. Cambridge University researchers say that maggots, mealworms, flies, seaweed and algae are among “future foods” that must be “mass-farmed” to combat malnutrition. The researchers claim that reservations about eating new foods such as insects could be overcome by using them as ingredients rather than eating them whole. They say current menu staples such as burgers, pasta and energy bars can all contain ground insect larvae and processed micro- and macro- algae. Their new report calls for “radical changes” to safeguard our food supply and combat malnutrition in the face of climate change, environmental degradation and epidemics.Would you have maggots for dinner  Join the debate in our comments They claim our future global food supply can’t be safeguarded by traditional approaches to improving food production. Instead, they suggest state-of-the-art, controlled-environment systems, producing new foods, should be integrated into the current system to reduce vulnerability to environmental changes, pests and diseases. The Cambridge research team, whose findings were published in the journal Nature Food, say that global malnutrition could be ‘eradicated’ by farming foods including larvae of insects such as the house fly, mycoprotein - protein derived from fungi, and macro-algae such as sugar kelp. They say such foods have already attracted interest as “nutritious” and “more sustainable” alternatives to traditional plant and animal-based foods. The ‘future foods’ can be easily grown on an industrial scale suitable for urban settings as well as isolated communities such as those on remote islands, according to the report.  In an approach the researchers call ‘polycentric food networks’, nutritional dishes could be produced locally and consistently by communities - reducing reliance on global supply chains. The Cambridge team analysed around  published scientic papers on dferent future food production systems. The most promising, including microalgae photo-bioreactors - devices that use a light source to grow microorganisms - and insect breeding greenhouses, reduce exposure to the hazards of the natural environment by farming in controlled environments. Study first author Dr Asaf Tzachor, a researcher at the Centre for the Study of Existential Riskat Cambridge University, said: “Foods like sugar kelp, flies, mealworm and single-celled algae such as chlorella, have the potential to provide healthy, risk-resilient diets that can address malnutrition around the world.  “Our current food system is vulnerable. It’s exposed to a litany of risks - floods and frosts, droughts and dry spells, pathogens and parasites - which marginal improvements in productivity won’t change. “To future-proof our food supply we need to integrate completely new ways of farming into the current system.” The report argues it is dangerous to rely on food produced through conventional farming and supply systems, which are at risk of serious disruption from several factors beyond human control. The researchers say that the Covid pandemic highlighted the vulnerability with Government-imposed restrictions on travel disrupting food production and supply chains across the world. Recent environmental challenges to food systems include wildfires and droughts in North America, outbreaks of African swine fever affecting pigs in Asia and Europe, and swarms of desert locust in East Africa. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Climate change is forecast to make such threats even worse. Catherine Richards, a doctoral researcher at CSER, said: “Advances in technology open up many possibilities for alternative food supply systems that are more risk-resilient, and can efficiently supply sustainable nutrition to billions of people.”She added: “The coronavirus pandemic is just one example of increasing threats to our globalised food system.“Diversying our diet with these future foods will be important in achieving food security for all.” The report states that two billion people currently experience food insecurity, including more than  million people undernourished and  million children suffering micro-nutrient deficiencies.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnUniversity of CambridgeEducationClimate changeFishingFloods

title: monster belgravia who slayed old
story: NewsMonster of Belgravia who slayed old ladies and butchered priest wont be freedEXCLUSIVE: Patrick Mackay, dubbed the Monster of Belgravia, slaughtered two pensioners and butchered a priest with an axe - the son of a victim of an unsolved murder said everybody knows hes killed moremirrorShareCommentsByTom Pettor:,  MAY NewsPatrick Mackays crimes shocked Britain in the s " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeOne of Britainaposs longest serving prisoners will remain in jail  years after completing his minimum sentence, the parole board has ruled. Patrick Mackay, , dubbed the “Monster of Belgravia”, strangled two old ladies and butchered a Catholic priest with an axe.But Mackay confessed to eight more killings - then denied it. All of the attacks remain unsolved. Police were asked to probe the cases in , delaying his parole hearing. The board has now decided not to make findings of fact in relation to those cases due to the “passage of time” and “absence of complete evidence”. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  It said in a decision summary released on Thursday: “The  found that it should consider some of the allegations but decided that these did not affect its assessment of Mr Mackay’s risk.” Mackay was  when he was convicted of strangling and stabbing Isabella Grfiths, , in Belgravia, central London in  and Adele Price, , a year later. He was further convicted of murdering -year-old Catholic priest Anthony Crean in the Kent village of Shorne in .  Mackay, who has changed his name to David Groves, was jailed for le for manslaughter, by reasons of diminished responsibility. Another  offences were taken into consideration by the trial judge, including robberies and thefts. He had also been charged with two further murders, which denied committing, which were ordered by the trial judge to “lie on file”.  MacKay has been in open conditions since . The  said it considered a dossier of more that  pages and heard evidence from his probation officer, the official supervising his case in prison, a psychologist and an independent psychologist. The parole board said: “After considering the circumstances of his offending, the progress made while in custody and the evidence presented at the hearings, the  was not satisfied that Mr Mackay was suitable for release.  “However, on assessing the benefits and risks of Mr Mackay remaining in open conditions, the  recommended that he should stay in the open estate.” Among the unsolved murders Mackay admitted and then denied was that of cafe owner Ivy Davies, , who was axed to death at her home in Southend, Essex, in February . title: prince harry says at least
story: NewsPrince Harry says ‘at least I wasn’t running down the strip’ in naked Las Vegas photosIn  Prince harry sparked a media frenzy after the saucy snaps were published on a US website. In one he was shown stood in front of a nude woman, covering his modesty with his handsmirrorShareCommentsByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  MAY NewsPrince Harry spoke candidly about a range of issues " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePrince Harry has addressed the infamous naked pictures taken during a Las Vegas holiday, telling his podcast host at least I wasnapost running down the strip. Back in  the Prince sparked a media frenzy after the saucy snaps were published on a US website. In one picture Harry was shown stood in front of a nude woman, covering his modesty with his hands. Another showed him leaving little to the imagination as he bear-hugged a naked woman from behind next to a pool table in a hotel room. The royal appeared on the Armchair Expert with Dax Shepherd podcast, and during the wide-ranging discussion he spoke about the notorious snaps.  Dax said: “In full disclosure, I am the most ill-informed person on the royal family, at least in my circle. You’re the only one I ever knew. “Simply because, you were in those awesome nude photos in Vegas. I literally said to myself, ‘this guy’s a party!’” Prince Harry replied: “You’re constantly looking for other people to balance out your own behaviour, right ”Dax agreed: “Exactly. Truthfully, it’s relatable. On top of that, I was like this motherf***** has got a good body, you were in tremendous shape.”  Harry said: “Now it’s getting weird” before saying the incident was a few weeks before I went to Afghanistan. Dax said: “This is the other reason I knew you. I was there in ’ and the big hubbub was that you were going to be arriving. I remember thinking, ‘oh wow, they send princes into battle ’. That was not what I thought happened.” Harry answered: “So much for keeping it quiet. At least I wasn’t running down the Strip, stripping, or more naked, at least.” Dax added: “You could have been one of the dancing boys of Afghanistan, do you know about that ” Keep up to date with all the latest news from the Queen, Charles, William, Kate, Harry, Meghan, George, Charlotte, Louis, Archie and the rest of the family. Weaposll send the best Royal news directly to your inbox so you never have to miss a thing.to our newsletter here. During the discussion Harry also spoke of his le as a royal, which he compared to living in a zoo and being on The Truman Show. He also said he wants to break the cycle of the pain and suffering of his upbringing with his own children.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPrince HarryRoyal Family

title: top 10 covid hotspots cases
story: NewsTop  Covid hotspots with cases in schoolchildren tripling in northern townBolton has found itself at the top of the coronavirus case list, with a big outbreak of infections among school children fuelling a tripling of cases in seven daysmirrorShareCommentsByCharlotte CoxPaul GallagherMilo Boyd:,  MAY NewsThe coronavirus case rate has rocketed among young people in Bolton " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA huge spike in coronavirus cases in Bolton has been driven by an outbreak at schools. The number of positive tests being ed by under-s in the Greater Manchester town has tripled in a week.Boltonaposs infection rate is now the worst in the country, having doubled over the last week, Manchester Evening News reported. It is now at . cases per , people in the week ending May , figures released by Public Health England revealed. There have also been large increases among younger adults, who might have been exposed to the virus through their school age children. The data shows that there has so far been no increase in infections among the over s, who are the most vulnerable to serious illness caused by Covid-.  In the space of a couple of weeks, the number of cases has gone from around  a day to more than five times that now. The sudden surge means that Bolton neighbourhoods account for six out of the  regions nationally with the highest infection rates. Several other areas have seen big spikes in the number of cases detected over the past week. Erewash , Blackburn with Darwen , Bedfordand Meltonall saw signicant jumps. title: uk weather washout weekend ahead
story: NewsUK weather: Washout weekend ahead after Met Office warns rain to last until JuneWhile Friday will see downpours staying largely along the coast, as the weekend gets under way most parts of the UK will see torrential downpoursmirrorShareCommentsByRyan MerrieldReporterWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  MAY NewsRelentless rain has marred much of May already " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice Brits are bracing for a washout weekend with torrential rain set to lash the country amid warnings the miserable weather will stretch until June. The Met Office has said that miserable May is not likely to get any better in the coming days with heavy rain and thunderstorms set to batter the country.While Friday will see downpours staying largely along the coast, as the weekend gets under way most parts of the UK will see torrential downpours. Forecaster Alex Deakin said: The weather continues a messy pattern across the UK with most places looking fairly cloudy for much of Friday.  But a few spots will see some sunshine. There will again be some heavy showers developing but not as many as recent days and for quite a few Friday should be a dry day. He added: There is more wet weather in the offing towards towards the weekend. On Friday temperatures will begin in single digits for much of the day and there will be sporadic showers, mostly hitting coastal regions all across the south and west of the country. Highs will reach  C in the south towards the end of the day.  But by the weekend forecasters have warned of torrential weather for many parts of the UK, with only Scotland spared the full force of the downpour. Forecasters at the Met Office warned Brits to expect aposa lot of showersapos which will be aposheavy and thundery.apos Temperatures are also expected to be below average and just barely rising into double digits across the UK. It comes after forecasters warned that the unsettled weather, which has marred much of spring, will drag on for at least the next  days, and possibly even beyond then. Heavy showers and more thunderstorms are likely to be a fixture for a few weeks with the mercury reaching no higher than C, the Met Office said.  Forecaster Marco Petagna earlier told the Mirror: The longer range forecast suggests that by early June thereaposs a hint of things becoming drier and more settled. Before that, temperatures could reach close to or above the average. Most likely it will be the mid to high teens -  or C. It looks unsettled for the next week or so. The next  days are quite mixed. That means showers and longer spells of rain. Today A cloudy start for all with some sunny spells developing by day. Staying dry for most in the north and east but across southern England, Wales and particularly Northern Ireland some showers breaking out by day. Tonight Rain arriving from the southwest with some heavy bursts and moving northeast overnight. Much of Scotland and northern England staying dry. Cool in the far north. Saturday Cloudy with rain across much of the UK to start. This breaking down to showers again by day, heaviest in the south and west. Northern Scotland faring best. Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday Remaining changeable with sunny spells and scattered showers which will be locally heavy with a risk of hail and thunder, particularly in the south. Remaining rather cool.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMet OfficeWeather

title: wales pauses relaxing covid rules
story: NewsWales pauses relaxing Covid rules next week due to fears over Indian iantFirst Minister Mark Drakeford said the decision had to be taken because of fears that the Indian iant could spread further after  cases in Wales were confirmedmirrorShareCommentsByNilufer Atik:,  MAY NewsWales will not ease all of its restrictions and is being more cautious " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticePeople in Wales will still have to abide by strict social distancing rules from Monday, despite measures being relaxed where in the UK. The rule stating that those meeting up in public must stay two-metres apart will still have to be adhered to, despite no longer applying in Scotland and England. First Minister Mark Drakeford said the decision was taken because of concerns over the Indian iant of the virus. There have been  cases of the iant in Wales so far, with a concentration in the north-west of England causing concern due to its proximity and link with the Welsh north-east. Wales will move to alert level two on Monday with the reopening of indoor hospitality and entertainment venues, but Mr Drakeford said his Government would pause further easementsthe risks in doing so would be too great.  He told BBC Radio  Live: Within your own household bubble or extended household youaposll be able to make decisions about who you hug and who you cwtch. But weaposre not yet thinking, largely because of the Indian iant, weaposre not going to change the rules about people more generally. We expect the two-metre social distance to be sustained. Wales will move to alert level two on Monday with the reopening of indoor hospitality and entertainment venues, but Mr Drakeford said his Government would pause further easementsthe risks in doing so would be too great. We can change the rules, we donapost have to wait two or three weeks. If we get advice that says itaposs safe to move ahead on that, weaposll do so as soon as we get that advice.  But we are just pausing to make sure that we have the best possible evidence about the newly emerging risks that there may be because ofIndian iant. Since the start of the pandemic, the government in England has insisted close contact with other people is one of the easiest ways to spread Covid- and has advised against it. From Monday however, this advice will end and people will be allowed to hug their grandparents, parents, brothers, sisters, friends and anyone  who is close to them again. They will have the choice whether to socially distancethey want to. People in England and Scotland will also be allowed to go to the pub or restaurant with up to six people or two households, sit indoors and enjoy a meal and some drinks. All indoor entertainment venues including cinemas, museums and childrenaposs play areas will also be allowed to reopen. But Wales has held back relaxing restrictions on allowing small events and meeting people for fears it could prompt the Indian iant of Covid to spread.  On Friday, Mr Drakeford told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: We were considering a small number of further easements from Monday but have decided to hold back on those until we get the advice from Sagewho met yesterday, our own scientic advice which weaposll receive imminently, just to make sure that we are continuing to take a precautionary approach in case the Indian iant is on the march, and therefore Wales would be vulnerable to it as well. Askedhe would be prepared to delay further steps in his road mapadvice from Sage suggests it is necessary, Mr Drakeford said: Yes, we would. We tried our best to follow the scientic advice at every step andthe advice were to be that we should hold back on some further easements because the risks in doing so would be too great then certainly that is what we would do. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Mr Drakeford told Sky News ministers had thought about moving ahead with the reopening of smaller events as well as liberalising the rules in the way in which people can meet together, not just in their extended household but beyond that, with both now on hold. If the advice on the Indian iant is that it is safe to move ahead, we wonapost need to wait for the end of our next three-week cycle to do those things, but the Indian iant is giving us cause for concern, he said. We donapost know enough about whether it is more transmissible than the Kent iant, we donapost know enough about whether the vaccination programme is as effective in dealing with it as it is with other iants we have in Wales, and until weaposre a bit clearer on that I think it is sensible to take a precautionary approach.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnBBC Radio  LiveRadio R TodayFoodCoronavirusIndia

title: woman left note 22 year
story: NewsWoman left note on -year-olds grave reading ‘hahaha, looks like diabetes won’Simona Julius daubed the vile message on the headstone of -year-old Liam Scarman, who died of diabetes on Boxing Day in  - leaving the deceased mans relatives devastatedmirrorShareCommentsByOllie Buckley:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsSimona Julius was jailed for the vandalism " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA woman has been jailed after vandalising the grave of a diabetic young man with the words: Ha Ha Ha Liam. Looks like diabetes won again. Simona Julius, , daubed paint on the headstone of Liam Scarman - leaving his family devastated. Liam died of diabetes aged  on Boxing Day in  after a suffering a diabetic hypo. Julius wrote the words P*ssyhole bruv on the grave in paint and also left a note saying: Ha Ha Ha Liam. Looks like diabetes won again. It is unclear why she did it - but his family previously said they suspected the culprit was associated with a former love rival. She carried out the attack overnight between November  and  last year.  She was jailed for eight weeks at Bristol Magistrates Court on Wednesday over the damage to the headstone at Westerleigh Crematorium in Bristol. She had admitted criminal damage and two counts of malicious communications at an earlier hearing. She was also ordered to pay £ compensation to the family and handed a three-year restraining order. District Judge Lynne Matthews described Juliusapos actions as perplexing and wicked and struck at the very heart of the family. The crimes, just before the three-year anniversary of Liamaposs death in December , caused his family great distress. In a personal statement to the court, Liamaposs mother Sue Witt described how Juliusapos actions took over family membersapos lives.  She said: Losing a child is the worst possible grief you could imagine. It has consumed my le. Having found out that somebody had damaged Liamaposs grave just compounded all those emotions and undid the progress I had made in dealing with his death. aposI think people are wondering what kind of person Liam was, how horrible a person he must have been for somebody to damage his grave the way they did, when in reality everybody who knew him loved him. I never knew him to do anything nasty or horrible to anybody. I donapost understand why she did it. Some of the notes were addressed to Liamaposs father, plumber and heating engineer Trevor Scarman, , who said in his statement: When I found out Liamaposs headstone had been vandalised, I had a numb feeling that went through my body. My initial reaction was why   Why had someone damaged it  Why just Liamaposs was targeted  How anyone can write such disgusting things about my son I just cannot believe. The physical damage has been repaired but the emotional damage will take far longer to repair. Itaposs like someone is sticking a kne in and twisting it. Our family are completely distraught. To commit an act of criminal damage like this along with vile notes addressed to me has left me feeling devastated. Investigating officer PC Kyle Maywood of the said: Iaposm glad that we were able to identy the culprit and bring some relief to the family, but Julius has never answered the question of what motivated her to act as she did and cause such distress. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  I hope the sentence will help Liamaposs family to put this behind them so they are able to remember him as their much-loved son and brother and not Juliusapos hateful actions. I also hope the case gives other victims of disability hate crime the confidence to report incidents to us. PC Maywood added: I would like to thank the members of the public who provided crucial information after seeing the appeals for information and calling in. Liam, who worked in insurance sales, died at his dadaposs house in Winterbourne Down., Glos, while living with his brother Oliver and girlfriend.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMcDonalds CorporationBoxing DayCourt caseCriminal damageCrimeCocaineDiabetesHate crime

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAn expectant dadaposs reaction to the gender of his new baby has ided opinions online.Matt shared footage of his gender reveal party on TikTok, where heaposs known as @matthb. In the clip that has been viewed more than , times, Matt and presumably his partner can be seen surrounded by their loved ones - all of which are clearly very excited to see the sex of the baby. When the time comes to pop the balloon, Matt takes hold of it firmly as his partner pops it with a pin.Pink balloons, confetti and silly string appear - indicating the pair are expecting a little girl.  But whilst the rest of the family are seen celebrating the exciting news, Matt simply throws the popped balloon on the floor and mutters something inaudible.Since being posted, the video has racked up more than , likes and hundreds of comments from ided viewers.One person wrote: Don’t worry. Your daughter won’t want you either. His daughter is going to be heartbroken when she sees this when she is older. Whatever biased opinions should disappear when you are having children,” another person commented. A third person replied: I hope his daughter doesn’t see this when she’s older. He is lucky to even have kids. I wonder what the family said after they stopped recording. But others took to his defence as they said thereaposs nothing wrong with having a preferred gender. One person put: At least he is honest, every man wants a boyyou already have a girl. If I was the daughter seeing this I would it’s hilarious, commented another viewer.Whilst someone  wrote: Just because he was disappointed doesn’t mean he’s going to love the baby any less.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice If youaposre an anxious person, you might not be able to resist the urge to Google your symptoms when youaposre feeling a little bit under the weather.One woman recently did this after having pain in her stomach. She initially thought she was fine, but after turning to the internet for some advice on her stomach ache, she became concerned that she was suffering with something much more serious. The woman, named Jenny Pearce, quickly made an appointment with her doctor to discuss her self-diagnosis.She arrived at the surgery to request a prostate exam as she was worried she might have prostate cancer - but then, much to her surprise, the doctor just started laughing.Jenny recounted her blunder in a video on TikTok under the username @adventure_jenny. She explained: Jenny had a stomach ache, but she was fine... Jenny wasnapost fine. Jenny Googled her symptoms and found she had prostate cancer.Jenny actually went to the doctors to ask for tests... The doctor laughed at her because she doesnapost have a prostate.She captioned the post, admitting: This is actually a true story.  The video quickly went viral, being watched more than one million times and garnering over , likes.One person commented: The curse of what is known was aposDr Googleapos. Another wrote: Jenny I did the same thing at . Doctor almost passed out laughing and then explained I didnapost have a prostate. A third replied: Google always says we are done for lol. Someone  proclaimed: Oh gawd love ya! That made me laugh... but as someone who is on the anxious side, I get it! A dferent user added: My dad had gas once but called the ambulance because he thought he was dying. He farted it out by the time the ambulance arrived.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: accidental wuhan coronavirus lab leak
story: NewsAccidental Wuhan coronavirus lab leak theory remains viable, scientists claimAn accidental Wuhan lab leak of the Covid virus "remains viable" as Stanfords David Relman said escapes "happen far more often than anyone would like to admit"mirrorShareCommentsByClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe Institute of Virology in Wuhan with refrigerators used to hold dferent virus strains" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice A group of leading scientists has said the possibility that coronavirus accidentally escaped from the Wuhan lab in China remains viable. In a letter published in the journal Science,  researchers from Stanford, Hard, MIT and Cambridge blasted the World Health Organizationand scientists who followed it for failing to consider that there may have may been an accidental lab escape of the virus.The Wuhan Institute of Virology is where the case of coronavirus was first detected in December . But a WHO task force spent four weeks investigating the outbreak in Wuhan in January and February and concluded it was extremely unlikely that it was caused by a lab leak.  It instead found there was more chance the outbreak occurred due to “zoonotic spillover” from bats to humans through another animals. Covid-, which emerged in China in late , has killed . million people, cost the world trillions of dollars in lost income and upended normal le for billions of people. The latest letter said the WHO investigation didnapost make a balanced consideration of the theory that it may have come from the Wuhan lab and called for a proper investigation into the matter.  We must take hypotheses about both natural and laboratory spillovers seriously until we have sufficient data, the letter reads. In this time of unfortunate anti-Asian sentiment in some countries, we note that at the beginning of the pandemic, it was Chinese doctors, scientists, journalists, and citizens who shared with the world crucial information about the spread of the virus—often at great personal cost. David Relman, the Stanford microbiologist who organised the letter, said: We know that laboratory accidents happen far more often than anyone would like to admit.” “And that includes the very best labs, including those here in the United States.” He goes on saying: Theories of accidental release from a lab and zoonotic spillover both remain viable. The WHO task force investigating the origin of the virus said in March that it was probably transmitted from bats to humans through another animal. It was further reported that the facilities had high-quality biosafety levels, and there had been no reports of similar illnesses among staff during the months before the pandemic hit. Employees had also not tested positive for Covid in subsequent blood screening for antibodies, the report said. In view of the above, a laboratory origin of the pandemic was considered to be extremely unlikely, it said.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnMassachusetts Institute of Technology Hard UniversityWorld Health OrganizationCoronavirus

title: israel drag gaza to depths
story: NewsIsrael will drag Gaza to depths of hell with plan for ground war against militantsAs the Palestinian death toll passed , with  children, Christian Aid warned they will take us into the depths of hellIsrael conducts a threatened ground warmirrorShareCommentsByChris HughesDefence and Security Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsA ball of fire engulfing the Al-Walid building which was destroyed in an Israeli airstrike on Gaza city early in the morning " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeIsraeli commanders were ­on Thursday drawing up plans for a ground war against Gaza’s militants, despite warnings they could drag the region to “the depths of hell”. A ground offensive plan will be presented to Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu today as the Palestinian death toll passed , with  children, this week. The number of injured Palestinians is approaching , including  children. Despite campaign groups calling for a ceasefire, there is little sign of either side halting the cross-border barrage. Tonight the charity Christian Aid said: “Even without a threatened ground invasion these figures will go up with one, they will take us into the depths of hell. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section  The international community cannot afford to continue failing in their responsibility to use every possible measure to stop the violence.” Yesterday sirens blared in southern Israel as a barrage of  rockets screamed out of Gaza almost simultaneously. Israeli sources said the government was determined to avoid a ground war, mindful of the  Gaza War that killed more than , Palestinians and  Israelis.  One source said: “Plans are being drawn up for a ground offensive, even though the Israeli Defence Force has inflicted serious damage on the Hamas military leadership. There is only so much Israeli intelligence can do in terms of picking out Hamas buildings to hit. “A ground offensive... unthinkable just days ago, remains nevertheless on the table.”  Israel declined a ceasefire offer from Hamas yesterday, “back-channelled” via Russia. It came despite the group launching , rockets at Israel since Monday, killing six civilians and a soldier. Among those killed by Israel are nine senior Hamas leaders.  Many of the Palestinian group’s bases are ruined. As Israeli troops gathered at the Gaza border on Thursday, one Israeli minister said after a meeting with Mr Netanyahu: “The campaign is still far from over. Whatever we don’t do now we will have to do in six months or a year from now.” The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  As well as rocket attacks, gangs of Jewish and Arab men have been fighting. Twenty people were hurt in city Lod, in Israel, where a state of emergency has been declared. Two people were shot and wounded and an Israeli Jewish man was stabbed by an Arab on Thursday. Another Jewish man was in hospital after an Arab gang beat him with iron bars in the northern city of Acre. In Jerusalem, a -year-old Arab was stabbed in the neck.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnHamasChristian AidGaza WarSoldiersIsraelMiddle EastMiddle East

title: man who used kfc glitch
story: NewsMan who used KFC glitch to order £, worth of chicken for free jailedBetween the gang, they stole a combined total of £, worth of free takeaway food before they were caught and jailed for their crimesmirrorShareCommentsByEmma Grimshaw:,  MAY NewsThe man, named as Xu from China, managed to swindle free chicken " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA -year-old student who ordered £, worth of free food after discovering a glitch in KFC’s online ordering system has been jailed. The man, named as aposXuapos from China, managed to swindle free chicken after discovering a loophole in the fast-food giantaposs voucher system, which he used for six months. He also shared the secret with four friends who collectively took a combined total of £, worth of food before they were caught.Ordering a takeaway via KFC’s phone app, Xu was using a voucher in April  when he discovered the glitch.Xu was jailed for two and a half years and fined £ while his friends were jailed for a period between  months and two years.  Between April and October that year, he effectively managed to generate endless free food vouchers by switching between the KFC app and the company’s store on WeChat, China’s equivalent of WhatsApp. Using this method, he found he could place an order using the voucher but it would also still remain in his account. Xu was using the hack to make money by selling on meals to friends. Xu then sold on some of the meals for a cut-price to his classmates while also eating them himself. His friends, who exploited the glitch in a similar fashion got away with free food worth between £, and £, each. The group was eventually caught and they admitted committing fraud. This week, at a court in Shanghai, Xu was jailed for two and a half years, while his friends were jailed for between two years and  months.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnWhatsAppKFCApps
