page has been set up and is ready to be launched in the hope that residents will dig deep to help keep the town looking its best.John Gray, from Gala in Bloom, said: ldquoNow that the floral displays in Bank Street gardens, Old Gala House, War Memorial and Gala Aisle are the responsibility of the community council , the greatest challenge will be to raise the funds required annually to retain those floral displays.:Galashiels: What you will see the next time you walk along Channel StreetldquoPrior to COVID, the Galashiels councillors had agreed to re-establish some assistance from the parking money, but because of the very limited use of the car parks, this assistance is not expected to be available for this summerrsquos planting.ldquoThe community council is grateful for monies already offered from the Hayward Sanderson Trust, Galashiels British Legion, Galashiels Rotary Club, from the customers of Alex Dalgetty Sons Bakers and theGray Sanderson Trust and, together with monies from the CC funds, this year is affordable.ldquoHowever, to prepare for future years we will be launching an appeal to lsquoSave the Public Gardens Fundrsquo and we are also looking for volunteers to join the Gala in Bloom group, who have already been offered assistance from a Girl Guide group and the ex-Braw Lads and Lasses.

title: election-snp-candidate-christine-grahame-wins-seat
story: CHRISTINE Grahame from the Scottish National Partyhas been elected as the MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale following the  Scottish Parliament election.Voters in Scotland went to the polls on Thursday , with counts held across the country yesterday and today .After ballot papers were totted up in Kelso today, Ms Grahame was declared the victor in her constituency. She won the previous Holyrood contest in .This time round, Ms Grahame received a total of , votes - up from , in .Second place has gone toScottish Conservative candidate Shona Haslam .In Ms Grahames victory speech, she sent a message to Prime Minister Boris Johnson.She said: ldquoI would like to say this to the electoratehellip Isnrsquot it wonderful to have such a turnout across Scotland for a Scottish Parliament election ldquoWhether you have voted for me or not, as I have done for the last times I have been elected, I will work for you no matter how you voted.ldquoAnd I know that is true of all the MSPs in the Scottish Parliament. Wersquore not partisan, any of us, when wersquore working for our constituents.ldquoAcross Scotland, I want to say thishellip First of all, this is the best constituency in Scotland,not the entire world.ldquoAnd the second thing I want to say about the vote is thishellip We will have, for the fourth term, an SNP government. And that is extraordinary.ldquoSecondly, there will be a majority in that parliament who have voted for people to have a choice that is to have a referendum, at an appropriate time, on whether or not Scotland becomes an independent country.ldquoAnd I want to say this to Boris Johnsonhellip What is the democratic way for the Scottish people to voice their will, other thanto go to the ballot box and, with proportional representation,a majority of MSPs who want a referendum ldquoIf that is not the way to do it, Boris, you tell us the way to do it.RESULTS:Christine Grahameshyndash ,.Shona Haslamndash ,.Katherine Sangsterndash ,AC Mayndash ,Dominic Ashmolendash ,Michael James Banksndash

title: election-result-christine-grahame-shona-haslam-react
story: CHRISTINE Grahame says she is ldquoabsolutely thrilled about increasing hermajority in Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale.Voters went to the polls on Thursdayfor the Scottish Parliament election contest.And todaySNP candidate Ms Grahame was declared the winner at the count in Kelso.The re-elected Ms Grahame received a total of , votes - up from , in .Her majority has risen from , to ,.Great that people turned outFollowing thedeclaration, Ms Grahame said: ldquoI am absolutely thrilled to have increased my majority, even with a Green candidate standing.ldquoThey took , votes and I actually thought my vote would go down, but Irsquove managed to increase it.ldquoThat, I hope, is vindication of the years I have represented this area, of the local campaign, of my campaign team and the national campaign team.ldquoIt was a strange campaign. I had never met any of the candidates personally, except for Shona Haslam, until today.ldquoI wasnrsquot able to go door-knocking and kept very low key. There were no hustings, no atmosphere but the great thing is, is that people turned out.ldquoMaybe we should do it this way every time, without the COVID.ldquoMy priority now is getting back to my desk to deal with cases - cases that have to be continued and cases that I had to park, as I wasnrsquot allowed to do them during this period.ldquoCases will be my priority. I am already activated. My parliamentary pass is live, so I can go back.ldquoObviously, not this weekend. I might go and see my grandchildren as they have not seen me for ages.ldquoBut on Monday, Irsquoll be back at my desk.Haslam enjoyed campaignSecond place went to Scottish Conservative candidate Shona Haslam .Mrs Haslam, the leader of Scottish Borders Council leader, told this newspaper:ldquoI am really pleased with the increase in the vote share.ldquoI think with the turnout being so high, it was always going to be dficult to call, so I am really pleased we have managed to increase our vote share here.ldquoI love campaigning, getting out and about to meet people and talking about the issues that are really important to people.ldquoI have really enjoyed this campaign.Askedshe had a message to her voters, she said: ldquoI wonrsquot let you down. I will be back.The turnout for the Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale constituency was  per cent .That is an increase on , when it was at . per cent .RESULTS:Christine Grahamendash ,Shona Haslamndash ,Katherine Sangsterndash ,AC Mayndash ,Dominic Ashmolendash ,Michael James Banksndash

title: selkirk-seven-new-shops-open-amid-business-boom-town
story: A BORDERS townis said to be experiencing a ldquorenaissance, with seven new shops having thrown open their doors recently.A iety of stores have joined the high street in Selkirk, some of them offering products and services previously not found in the town.A spokesperson for Explore Selkirk said: ldquoSelkirk is going through a renaissance, and the town has a real feeling of optimism.ldquoWhilst other high streets have struggled to keep shops open during the pandemic, Selkirk has seen seven new shops open in the town centre.The Border toured the town with Explore Selkirk, meeting the business owners.Many were upbeat about launching during the pandemic.Number One deli. Photo: Phil WilkinsonldquoTo be honest, it probably couldnrsquot have happened at a better time, said Tracey Ward, who runs Number One delicatessen with her husband Trevor.She added: ldquoSome folk thought we were mad opening up in the middle of a pandemic but itrsquos been really good ndash in fact wersquove been able to concentrate on it as well.The couple also own The Fleece Bar and Kitchen in the town.Trevor added: ldquoWersquove been open eight weeks now. We were well supported by the local community when the first lockdown came.ldquoTherersquos a lot of good will out there and wersquore thankful for that.The Peony Rose Coffee House. Photo: Phil WilkinsonCatherine Inglis took over the Selkirk Deli and renamed it the Peony Rose Coffee House.She offered on-the-door takeaways before being allowed to welcome guests indoors last week.Catherine said: ldquoItrsquos been a challenge.ldquoBut Irsquove been very lucky as Irsquove had the opportunity to get it how I want.ldquoEvery cloud has a silver lining.For some local residents, searching for tools and DIY items use to mean having to travel to shops in other Borders towns now, however, shoppers looking for lightbulbs, tools and even pet supplies can find them closer to home at Ideal Hardware  Home Essentials.Lorna Han is the owner of the store, which opened in October.She told this newspaper: ldquoBusiness has been steady, wersquove been well supported.Meanwhile, on Market Place, The General Storerepairs broken items and sells upcycled goods.The General Store. Photo: Phil WilkinsonFounded by Sue Briggs and Dot Torrance, the repair shop has been operating since before Christmas - but the retail side of The General Store has only just opened.The teamrsquos ethos is that damage doesnrsquot make something useless.ldquoSomething can be beautul evenitrsquos damaged, Sue said.They hope that by offering repair services, as well as selling beautul upcycled items made by local creators, they can start a conversation about eco-friendly living and making the most of what we have now.Basanti India. Photo: Phil WilkinsonBasanti India ndash which sells ethically sourced gts and accessories and did have a temporary presence in the town ndash has now moved to permanent premises.Owner Imogen Kennedy told us: ldquoI lived in India for  years I know all my providers.ldquoI started in the pop-up on Tower Street ndash itrsquos a great launch pad.ldquoItrsquos really nice to have a permanent place on the high street.Skinnys. Photo: Phil WilkinsonAnd for anyone with a sweet tooth, Skinnyrsquos on Market Place serves waffles, ice-cream and a range of lunchtime snacks.Co-owner Shirley Singhtoor said: ldquoWersquove had lots of interest.ldquoWe just want to spread the word and see how things go.Burnside Gallery. Photo: Phil WilkinsonAlso newly opened is the Burnside Gallery and Frames, run by Javier Ternero and Charly Murray.They said: ldquoSelkirk has been wonderful, very welcoming. Therersquos a ersity of businesses here.For more information on the range of businesses in Selkirk, you can visit: exploreselkirk

title: asda-announce-major-changes-coming-every-uk-store
story: Asda has published its first environmental, social and governancereport and with it promised changes affecting every store in the UK.The supermarket giant has set out its commitments to a sustainable business strategy in the future.The report interviewed , customers and found that shoppers had three priorities.According to the report, customers want more affordable greener choices, commitments to reduce single-use plastic and cutting food waste.The supermarket said it is now committed to becoming a net zero carbon business by .Asda ndash one of the UKrsquos big six UK supermarket retailers ndash will join rivals such as Sainsburyrsquos and Aldi in becoming more environmentally friendly.Asda bosses plan to remove three billion pieces of plastic from products within the next four years.They also want to ensure its top  commodities, including cotton and cocoa, are sustainably sourced by .The chain has also pledged to increase the proportion of own-brand products that are low in fat, sugar and salt to % by .Roger Burnley, Asda CEO and President, said:ldquoAsda has always been a retailer that sits at the heart of the communities it serves and the events of the last  months have highlighted the important role we play in helping to tackle societal challenges.ldquoDespite the challenges of the pandemic, we have not lost sight of our wider ESG responsibilities and this report provides an update of where Asda is now on the issues that matter most to our colleagues, customers and communities and importantly where we want to be in the future."It builds upon our existing create change for better commitments and the resilience we have shown during the last  months means we are well positioned to help customers make greener, healthier and responsible choices when they shop with us.

title: 20mph-limits-scottish-borders-council-starts-consultation
story: BORDERS residents can now have their say on the mph speed trial which began last year.As part of the Spaces for People programme, the reduced limit was introduced in more than  towns and villages in the region.And todayan online consultation has been launched, so people can share their views on the trial ndash for example, whether they think any roads should change back to mph.Gordon Edgar, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, transport and travel, said: ldquoThe mph trial, which has been in place for the last seven months, was introduced to make it easier and safer for people to walk, cycle and wheel for everyday journeys.ldquoWith it having been in place for a signicant amount of time during the coronavirus pandemic, we now want to get feedback from Borderers as to how effective it has been."As part of the consultation, which will run until June , contributors will be asked how the scheme impacted travel and whether they chose to walk or cycle more as a result.During the trial, data was collected to show how the new limits affected average speeds. The results can be accessed at scottishborders.tracsis-tads conduit bordersOne example is the .mph reduction in average speed at Hillside Terrace, Selkirk .Mr Edgar said: "Whether you are a keen walker or cyclist, have a business which operates in the Borders, live in this part of the country or drive on the roads across the region, I would urge you to feedback your specic experiences with the trial and how it has impacted your travel.ldquoItrsquos important that we get as many responses to this consultation as possible, to help inform any permanent changes the council makes following the trial.ldquoThese will be made purely on an inidual basis, based on the specic needs of each community, the feedback we receive through the consultation and the impartial data collected across theof the trial.The consultations findings will be reported later this year, detailing which parts of the scheme will be kept ndashany.Cyclists, pedestrians, residents, business owners and drivers are all asked to contribute to the consultation.To share your views, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk mphThe speed limits were introduced by Scottish Borders Council, working with the Scottish Government, Transport Scotland and Sustrans.

title: covid-scotland-rules-meeting-inside-home
story: From next Monday you will be allowed to meet another household inside your own home for the first time this year.All council areas in Scotlandare expected to move from level three to at leastlevel two from Monday, May .The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.These changes will mean that you will be allowed to meet indoors, including homes, as long as you stick to the restrictions.Heres what you need to know:Meeting in homesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially in a home is fourwhich can be from twohouseholds, including for overnight stays.Children under the age of  do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoorsChildren under  do not need to maintain physical distance from others.When you meet people from another household indoors you should:Minimise the number of meetings you have with people from other households each day.Stay at least twometres apart from anyone who is not part of your household.Maintain hand and cough hygiene.Avoid touching hard surfaces with your hands.Wash your hands when you arrive, when you leave, when you get home and especially before eating or after touching surfaces.Not sharing food or utensils.Keep rooms well ventilated,possible ndash consider opening windows or a door.

title: coronavirus-borders-weekend-cases-shown-latest-data
story: THE Borders has recorded three new cases of coronavirus over the weekend, figures show.The Scottish Government publishes an update every day at pm.Today , the figures show the Borders has recorded , cases since the pandemicbegan - meaning the tally has risen by three since Friday .The Borders data shows there are still fewer than five people in hospital with the virus, which has been the case since February .

title: michael-gove-makes-scottish-borders-council-comment-bbc
story: THE leader of Scottish Borders Councilsays she was ldquodelighted to hear Michael Goversquos comments on the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr Show.When Mr Marr interviewed the Minister for the Cabinet Office on Sunday , Mr Gove suggested the UK Government is keen to work closely with local authorities in Scotland ndash including SBC.SBC leader Shona Haslam, also of the Conservatives, said: "I am absolutely delighted that the UK Government will be supporting councils in this way."When Mr Gove was interviewed, he said that as part of the UK Governmentrsquos lsquoLevelling Uprsquo project, Whitehall could work directly with Scottish councils to provide funding.When asked by Mr Marrthese plans were aiming to bypass the Scottish Government and put the Scottish Parliament "back in its box", Mr Gove said: "Certainly not."We want to work with both."I think its critically important we work with the Scottish Government and with local government as well."We have already seen opportunities to do just that."When we announced that we were going to work with both Holyrood, but also local authorities, I think it was the leader of Glasgow council ndash an SNP politician ndash who welcomed that, along with the leaders of Aberdeen council, Borders council and so on."To my mind, its an example of Team UK working together in everyones interests."lsquoLevelling Uprsquo is a Westminster White Paper, to be published later this year, which "will focus on challenges including improving living standards, growing the private sector and increasing and spreading opportunity".Mrs Haslam told the Border : "I am very excited about the opportunity to work with the UK Government on funding proposals and have already had several useful meetings with our MPs for this area and the Scotland Office.ldquoI would encourage anyone with ideas for local projects to contact their local councillor to discuss options.

title: covid-scotland-can-level-2-lockdown
story: All council areas in Scotlandwill move to Level  on Monday,with the possible exception of Moray which will stay in Level  and several islands will move to Level .The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK have said the threat level should be lowered from "level "to "level ", thanks to the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Here is what you can and cannot do in Level  lockdown:Can I meet peopleinside my home Yes but the maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Social distancing rules do not need to be followed.Can I get a pint or a meal indoors Yes. Indoors it will be sixadults from threehouseholds in an indoor public place like a cafeacute, pub or restaurant.Outdoors eight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.Under s do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoors.AmI allowed to goto the shops Yes, all non-essential shops will be open for business so you will be able to head to your favourite retailers.Can I travel around Scotland Yes, you will be able to travel anywhere across Scotland and the UK.However, as lockdown levels change, people in Level must not enter Levels - or Level  area unless for a permitted reason.Can I go on holiday Staycations will be permitted with travel restrictions lted and tourist accommodation will reopen.However, socialising rules must still apply.International travel is also allowed in  green list areas.It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Will bars, restaurants andcafes be open Yes, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars can open indoors until : with two-hour pre-booked slots.They can open outdoors within local licensing conditions for the consumption of food and alcoholic drinks.The maximum number of people you can meet indoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is sixwhich can be from up to threeseparate households.The maximum number of people you can meet outdoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is eightwhich can be from up to eight separate households.Takeaway service will also continue to be open.Am I able to go to the gym Yes, gyms and indoor sports facilities including swimming pools and leisure centres will be open for inidual exercise.Personal training and coaching are also permitted,Group activity will be permitted for under s.Can I play contact sports Yes, all organised outdoor sports are allowed provided appropriate safety measures are followed.Indoor contact sports are not permitted, except for professional sport.Will cinemas be open Yes - as willtheatres, bingo halls,music venues, comedy clubs,amusement arcades and casinos.Guidance is being produced which may allow higher capacities to be agreed with the local authority Scottish Government depending on the event.Can Isee my friends and family Yes, groups ofeight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.It is worth noting that under s do not count towards restricted numbers or households outdoors.Can I go into stadiums and attend events Yes.Outdoor seated and open space events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Outdoor grouped standing events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Small seated indoor events are advised to operate with a maximum of  people.Can I take public transport You should continue to active travelwhere possible and avoid car sharing with people outside of your extended household.Face coverings compulsory on public transport and, due to limited capacity,you are using public transport then plan ahead.What about childcare Nurseries, childminders and regulated school-age childcare providers are open with standard protective measures are in place.Informal childcare such as family and friendsare permitted.Can my child take part in after school activities Yes, but it will be subject to guidance.Can zoos and tourist attractions reopen Yes, all visitors centres can reopen for business.Should I still work from home You are encouraged to work from home where possible.Can I visit people in the hospital Yes, but the recommended family support from at least onevisitor per patient.Am I able to visit my loved ones in care homes Yes, however, the recommended minimum of twovisits per week, one person at a time.Will college and universities be open Yes, but it willbeblended learning.Can I get married Yes, and  people are allowed to attend the ceremony and thewedding reception.Alcohol is also permitted.Am I allowed to attend a funeral A maximum of  people are allowed to attend a funeral service and alcohol is permitted.Can I visit my place of worship Yes, places of worship will be open.Will libraries be open Yes, public buildings such as libraries or community centres will be open.Some public buildings will operate an online booking system and some may have dedicated opening times for high-risk groupsAre driving lessons allowed Yes, driving lessons are allowed.Can I get work done indoors Work, such as home decorating, repairs etc areallowed indoors.Am I allowed to move home Yes, you are allowed to move home.Will hairdressers and beauty services stay open Yes, all close contact services, including mobile, may operate providing they follow Scottish Government guidance to ensure the safety of customers and staff.

title: glasgow-science-centre-free-attend-innovation-event
story: Glasgow Science Centre is holding its second online festival - May, and everyone aged  and upwards is invited to attend.Curious About Innovation will celebrate the innovative spirit in all of us, and how that spirit can change the world.The three-day programme of live talks, interviews, games and resources will reveal how technology and innovation are solving global challenges. The festival is being delivered with support from the Inspiring Science Fund provided by Wellcome, UKRI and BEIS with additional support from JP Morgan, Mathworks and University of Strathclyde.Top innovators from Scotlandand around the world have signed up to take part. Experts from organisations like Rolls Royce, AAC Clyde Space, the National Oceanographic Centre, IBM and the Scottish Space School have all signed up.NASA astronauts and engineers will be beamed in from the USA to answer questions about le in space the Royal Navy will take everyone on a guided tour round a virtual submarine and the plans to get oysters cleaning the Clyde will be revealed.The festival is free and open to everyone, just register on https:curiousabout.glasgowsciencecentre.org .Click image to attend for freeStephen Breslin, chief executive of Glasgow Science Centre, said: ldquoCurious About Innovation has been designed to entertain and inspire everyone aged  and upwards.ldquoSome of the worldrsquos most exciting science and technology will be showcased in the festival. It will cover industries like space, construction, cyber security, health, robotics and the environment.ldquoThe festival will inspire the next generation of scientists and engineers by highlighting the career paths and employers that are available to young people in Scotland.Curious About Innovation is Glasgow Science Centrersquos second online festival. It builds on the themes connected with GSCrsquos IdeaNo exhibition, which everyone can visit in person when the science centre reopens.The festival also supports GSC Learning Labrsquos space module and GSCrsquos STEMFuturesrsquo programme, which is helping thousands of young people into STEM work experience and career choices.Curious About Innovation is free to everyone, but those aged  and upwards will get the most out of it. Visit https:curiousabout.glasgowsciencecentre.org for updates.Click image to attend for freeCurious About Innovation: HighlightsScotlandrsquos innovation in the space sector ,  May, -The space sector is booming in Scotland. Join AAC Clyde Space to find out about innovation and growth in the space sector and how we use satellites to communicate and collect information.NASA live talks,  May,    May, Join NASA engineers and astronauts as they give you the lowdown on living in space, and keeping astronauts comfortable and safe on orbit. Youll even have the opportunity to ask questions about their exciting careers.Virtual Submarine Tour with the Royal Navy,  May,  ndash Take a virtual tour of a Navy submarine, go behind the scenes and learn about the innovations and the practical engineering solutions within the vessel.Construction Innovation with Morrison Construction,  May,  ndash Take a virtual tour of a construction site, see how Morrison Construction uses the latest innovation and technology to design buildings on their sites. Hear how they use advanced low-energy construction to build sites with very low environmental impact.Jet Engine Evolution with Rolls Royce,  May ndash  ndash Take a virtual tour of the Rolls Royce site at Inchinnan! Go behind the scenes on the manufacturing journey to see how compressor aerofoils are made from beginning to end and understand theirwithin the jet engine. This workshop will also follow the evolution of the jet engine and how it has developed over the years to incorporate innovation as technology advances.Glasgow Tower Uncovered ndash Ideas StudioTake a tour of Glasgow Tower, an unique structure in Glasgow citys skyline. Get behind the scenes as we discuss some of the challenges it has faced, and the innovative solutions making this tower a Guinness World Record holder.Click image to join us for free

title: nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update-covid-rules-set-ease
story: Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that most of Scotland will enter Level  lockdown next week.People in Scotland will be able to hugged loved ones again from Monday ndash subject to restrictions ndash an emotional Nicola Sturgeon has said as she confirmed further lockdown easing.These changes will include meeting up to six people from three households socialising indoorsrestaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars openingindoors until :cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls reopening andquarantine-free international travel.It comes after the Covid- alert level in the UK was downgraded from Level  to Level  after a "consistent"fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK put it downto the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.Heres what you need to know:Scotland to enter Level The First Minister confirmed that the majority of Scotland will move to Level  lockdown from May .Moray will stay in Level and the Scottish Islands will move to Level  from Monday.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Household changesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis six people which can be from three households, including for overnight stays.Hugs are back!Nicola Sturgeon has confirmed that hugs will be allowed indoors in Scotland.The First Minister said: "From Monday,you are meeting friends and family, within the permitted limits of course, either indoors in a private dwelling or in your garden, our guidance will say that it is no longer necessary to maintain physical distance."Which means - and I actually feel a bit emotional as I say this - that from Monday, as long as you stay within permitted limits, you can hug your loved ones again."I know how desperate we all are for this - and so I donrsquot intend to immediately pour cold water on it - but there are two further points I really need to make."She added: "Close physical contact does still carry risk, I have to be clear about that."Soyou have loved ones who are vulnerable for any reason, please still be careful. And limit the overall number of people that you choose to have close physical contact with."Moray decisionNicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will not move to Level  and will stay in Level  for a "further period".The decision comes as health authorities in the area are currently dealing with "uncontrolled, sustained community transmission"of Covid-, with current restrictions failing to contain the spread.Latest statistics show Moray had . cases per , people in the seven days to May , signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of Scotland.Travel restrictions willbe brought into Moray and people should only enter there for essential purposes only.Ms Sturgeon said: "In recent days, as you will have seen, Moray has been experiencing a high and increasing number of cases with a small associated increase in hospital admissions."Indeed, public health experts consider that Moray is currently experiencing widespread community transmission."She added: "It is therefore highly probable that Moray will stay at level  for a further period."It is also important that we take precautions to reduce the risk of the transmission of Covid spreading from Moray to other parts of Scotland, as restrictions ease where.""SoMoray does stay in level  - which will be finally decided at the end of the week - we will also reimpose travel restrictions for a hopefully short period.This will mean that travel in and out of Moray will be limited to permitted purposes only."Islands changesMany islands in Scotland will move to Level  due to low case numbers.Nicola Sturgeon said:"For our island communities, the situation is dferent and much more positive."Case numbers have consistently been at very low levels for some time now."Many islands also now have very good vaccination coverage, and lateral flow tests are available for all people travelling to the islands from other parts of Scotland."For those reasons, we have decided that it is possible to ease restrictions more quickly for communities in the Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney for all islands in Highland, except Skye, given its fixed link and for the Inner Hebrides islands in Argyll - including Islay, Jura and Mull."All of these areas will move directly to level  from Monday, rather than to level ."International TravelPeople in Scotland will be able to travel to some foreign destinations without the need to quarantine on their .It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Nicola Sturgeon said: "At the outset, let me be very clear that we still intend to be highly cautious on international travel - given the risk of new iants - but we consider that the situation now allows us to begin a careful move away from blanket restrictions on non-essential travel."From Monday, we will move to a traffic light system, informed by risk assessments prepared by the Joint Biosecurity Centre. These assessments will be based on the state of the pandemic in each country across the world - including the presence of iants of concern."These green countries include:PortugalIsraelSingaporeAustraliaNew ZealandBruneiIcelandGibraltarFalkland IslandsFaroe IslandsSouth Georgia and the Sandwich IslandsSt Helena, Tristan de Cunh and Ascension IslandLatest case numbersThe First Minister was unable to update on the latest Covid numbers due to "IT issues".Nicola Sturgeon said:"I hope that will be resolved soon, and I can assure you that all of todays figures will be published just as quickly as possible."Youll be able to access them when theyre published on the Scottish Government website."

title: coronavirus-borders-update-shows-no-new-cases-last-day
story: NO new cases of coronavirus have been recorded in the Borders in the past  hours.The Scottish Government publishes an update every day at pm.Today , the figures show the Borders has recorded , cases since the pandemic began.The Borders data shows there are still fewer than five people in hospital with the virus, which has been the case since February .A total of , people have tested positive for COVID-across Scotland since the pandemic began in March .You might also be interested in:Borders man accused of raping five womento face total of  charges at trialMichael Goves comments about Scottish Borders Councilare welcomed by leadermph speed limits: Tell us what you think, says Scottish Borders Council

title: school-best-scotland-times-school-league-table-2021
story: Scotlandssecondary schools have been ranked based on this years highers results.The figures, which were published by The Times, show the performances of every secondary school inScotlandbased on the number of pupils achieving five or more highers.Jordanhill, Scotlands only government-aided secondary school, has topped the leaderboard for the sixth year in a row.The rest of the top  featured St. Ninians High School, Gryffe Hugh School, Dunblane High School, Bearsden Academy,Boroughmuir High School, Williamwood High School,Cults Academy andBishopbriggs Academy.Where does your childs school rank  Have a look in the full table from The Times league tablesbelow.

title: coronavirus-shona-haslam-move-level-2-lockdown-rules
story: THE leader of Scottish Borders Council has issued a message to people in the region ahead of a move to Level  of coronavirus lockdown restrictions.Earlier this week, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that the Borders would move down from Level of lockdown rules from Mondayndash along with the majority of Scotland.The changes will include six people from three households being allowed to meet inside and stay overnight, with no need to socially distance in private homes.Responding to the First Ministerrsquos announcement, council leader Shona Haslam, of the Conservatives, said: ldquoThe further easing of restrictions is welcome news for people in the Borders, whorsquove patiently followed all the guidance in place to keep everyone safe.:Break-in at Borders restaurant sparks appeal for information about  peopleldquoIt is also good news for our local hospitality and tourism businesses who Irsquom sure will see even more people coming through their doors in the weeks to come.ldquoIrsquod encourage everyone to continue doing what theyrsquove done so well ndash follow all the guidance in place and act responsibly.ldquoIf we all do this we will be able to ease restrictions even further and enjoy more freedom going forward.From May , eight people from eight households will be able to meet outdoors, with pubs and restaurants permitted to sell alcohol indoors.NHS Bordersrsquo director of public health, Tim Patterson, said the further easing of lockdown restrictions is ldquoreally positive news.:Michael Goves comments about Scottish Borders Council are welcomed by leaderldquoBeing able to see our loved ones in a private home is a big step in the right direction and Irsquom sure that will bring great comfort to Borderers, Dr Patterson said.ldquoIt is however really important that you remain cautious and take the necessary precautions such as opening windows to keep rooms well ventilated, avoid touching hard surfaces and maintaining good hand and cough hygiene to keep yourself and your loved ones safe.ldquoIt also remains important that you practice social distancing in public places and gardens."To help us keep on the right path, stick with the rules and continue protecting each other and our local health and social care services.ldquoFollowing the FACTS advice is really important, evenyou have received one or both doses of the COVID-vaccination.

title: galashiels-high-street-update-empty-polish-shop-building
story: THERE has been an update on the future of an empty shop on a Borders high street.Plans were lodged last year to turn the Polish Shop ndash a former grocery store ndash on GalashielsHigh Street into one two-storey house and a flat.At Galashiels Community Council last Wednesday , Rick Kenney said the plans have been re-submitted to Scottish Borders Councilto ldquomeet modern building standards.ldquoItrsquos been closed for a few years now, Mr Kenney said.ldquoIn July they submitted a plan to change it to some homes but keep the same design on the building on the outside.ldquoItrsquos another empty building that wersquore getting back into use.:mph speed limits: Tell us what you think, says Scottish Borders CouncilThere were no adverse comments submitted by the community council.When the initial plans were lodged last year, an SBC planning officer said: ldquoI recognise the loss of the retail use, but also note the building has had non-retail uses in the recent past .ldquoI accept the residential use may be a less vibrant contributor to the town centre, and that there are no other ground floor residential uses fronting the High Street.ldquoHowever, a residential use will, nonetheless, be a positive contributor, and this shop comprises an unremarkable and modest property located at the end of the town centre, well away from the principal activity area of the town.ldquoThere is also a range of uses in this part of town already, including residential uses on upper floors.ldquoA residential use on the ground floor would have a negligible effect on the strength of the town centre overall and the character of this end of the town, and would maintain the mixed use nature of this area.

title: galashiels-academy-new-school-plans-backed-full-council
story: PLANS to build the new Galashiels Academy have taken a step forward today .At a meeting, elected members agreed to take forward Scottish Borders Councils preferred site option for the new pound million community campus.For months campaigners have been voicing concernsover Option , which includes building in part of Scott Park.The meeting of the full council was told that  negative comments were recorded opposing the proposed site during the informal consultation period.But a report to members stated "there is widespread support amongst the school community and the wider silent majority for the project".During todays meeting, Galashielscouncillor Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said the new facilities were a "once in a generation opportunity".Sandy Aitchison, an independent councillor for the town, added he was "looking forward immensely" to seeing a new campus being built.

title: friends-reunion-premiere-date-confirmed-celebrity-guests-announced
story: Friendswillfor the highly anticipated reunion episode on May , it has been confirmed.The special episode will air on streaming service HBO Max as a trailer was released on social media.The clip shows all six original cast members - Courteney Cox, Jenner Aniston, Lisa Kudrow, Matt LeBlanc, Matthew Perry and David Schwimmer ndash walking arm-in-arm across a studio lot.The video was accompanied by a down-tempo version of the US sitcomrsquos theme, Irsquoll Be There for Youby The Rembrandts.Friendswas one of the biggest sitcoms on the planet in the s before it ended in  and now the show has a new generation of fans thanks to streaming services such as Netflix.Cox, who played Monica Geller, wrote on Instagram: ldquoThis kind of thing doesnrsquot happen every year, or even every , or  years. I feel so blessed to have had a chance to reunite with my Friendshellip and it was better than ever., px px  rgba margin:  auto max-width:px padding: width:.% width:-webkit-calc width: auto"display:block height:px margin: auto -px position:relative top:-px width:px"LoadingA post shared by Courteney Cox View on Instagram@-webkit-keyframes"dkaXkpbBxI" % %@keyframes"dkaXkpbBxI" % % ldquoFinally! Had a blast with the cast and a solid nap with LeBlanc, said Schwimmer, who played palaeontologist Ross Geller.Aniston, best known as Rachel Green, said: ldquoItrsquos official! The #FriendsReunion premieres May th on @HBOMax mdash could we BE any more excited !ldquoSo great to see you everyone, wrote LeBlanc, who played hapless actor Joey Tribbiani.HBO has also unveiled a star-studded line-up of celebrities who will appear as themselves.They include David Beckham, Justin Bieber, BTS, James Corden, Cindy Crawford, Cara Delevingne, Lady Gaga,Kit Harington, Tom Selleck, Reese Witherspoon and Malala Yousafzai.The cast will not be in character and will appear as themselves in the special, which was repeatedly delayed because of the pandemic after originally being set to arrive on the HBO Max streaming  in May last year.

title: kelso-high-school-homes-getting-built-former-site
story: WORK has started to build affordable homes on the former site of a Borders high school, according to Eildon Housing.The housing association is working with Kelso-based contractor M  J Ballantyne to create  extra care homes ndash also known as assisted living accommodation ndash at the previous base of Kelso High School.The building of the  homes is outlined as phase one and is expected to take two years.Phase two will then involve a further  homes including two two-bedroom properties with wheelchair access.Eildonrsquos chief executive Nile Istephan said: ldquoOur new strategy focuses on the responses given from the three key groups we consulted our customers, our stakeholders and our people .ldquoThe issues that came out most strongly were that we should continue to provide new high quality, affordable and sustainable homes for our communities and develop and deliver new services to respond to the specic needs of our older population, those living with dementia and groups vulnerable to becoming homeless.According to an Eildon spokesperson, architect Aitken Turnbullrsquos ldquosympathetic design for the Kelso homes includes retaining the ldquoart deco facade of the former school.Kelsorsquosnewly-built high school on Angraflat Road opened to students in .

title: chicago-cat-wows-onlookers-leaping-burning-multi-storey-building
story: A cat in Chicago had onlookers gasping as it leapt from the fth floor of a burning building.Chicago Fire Department was in attendance and recording footage of the blaze being tackled on Thursday when the black cat appeared at a broken window.After a short time assessing the situation, the moggy committed to its escape plan.Prompting screams from some at the scene, the fearless feline soared through the air, over a wall, and on to the grass.Having bounced off the turf it immediately wandered off, thankfully unharmed.ldquoIt went under my car and hid until she felt better after a couple of minutes and came out and tried to scale the wall to get back in, said fire department spokesman Larry Langford.Mr Langford said he was attempting to find the catrsquos owner.The video has been viewed more than , times, while no injuries were reported after the fire..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Chicago cat wows onlookers by leaping from burning multi-storey building

title: indian-coronavirus-variant-need-know-cases-continue-rise
story: New coronavirus cases involving the Indian iant have more than doubled in a week as Government ministers said they cannot rule out imposing local restrictions to suppress its spread.Data from Public Health Englandpublished on Thursday shows a steep rise in cases associated with B, which has been designated as a ldquoiant of concern, from  last week to ,.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the situation was being monitored carefully and the Government ldquowill not hesitate to take further actionnecessary.How many cases have been detected in the UK vw,vw,px, px"Surge testing is expected to be deployed where there is evidence of community transmission There are , confirmed cases of the B iant in the UK.The cases are spread across the country, with the majority in the North West, mainly in Bolton, Sefton in Merseyside, Blackburn in Lancashire, and London.What is being done We are deploying additional testing in an area where cases of the #COVIDiant first identied in India have been found.Over s who live, work or study in Formby, Sefton should take a PCR test from today.More info: ## https:t.co blpREyMf@seftoncouncilpic EIUXDGaImdash Department of Health and Social CareMay , Mobile testing units have been deployed in Bolton and door-to-door PCR Covid- testing has been offered to , residents.A vaccine bus has been set up to increase uptake among those who are eligible and a rapid response team of  nurses, public health advisers and environmental health officers has been sent in.Surge testing has also been deployed in Sefton, after cases of the Indian iant were confirmed in the Formby area as well as in parts of London, including Hillingdon, Hounslow, Redbridge, Tower Hamlets and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Cha.Alongside imposing local lockdowns, the Government is also considering bringing forward the date for a second dose of vaccine for eligible groups to increase protection as well as vaccinating younger people in multi-generational households.Will bringing forward second jabs help tackle the rise vw,vw,px, px"The Government is considering bringing forward second vaccine doses to help tackle the spread of the Indian iant When the national vaccine programme began in the UK, officials took the bold decision to delay administering booster shots so that more elderly and vulnerable people could more quickly receive their first shots.Studies have since shown that giving the second dose  weeks after the first, instead of  days, can produce a stronger immune response.Thus it remains to be seen whether bringing forward the date of the second dose could help curb rising infections.Paul Hunter, professor in medicine at the University of East Anglia, said ldquosurge vaccination will ldquopossibly work, but it is ldquonot an easy question either way.He told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme: ldquoOne of the dficulties with vaccination is that it does take a couple of weeks to work, soyoursquore moving vaccines away from areas where they currently donrsquot have much Indian iant and that is increasing, by the time you start getting round to vaccinating that group again when maybe the epidemic, the Indian iant, is increasing rapidly again, probably you might well have been able to stop thatyou hadnrsquot erted vaccines to surge areas.ldquoSo itrsquos not an easy question either way, to be honest.Is the B iant driving the second wave in India #CoronaVirusUpdates:#COVIDtesting status update:@ICMRDELHIstated that ,,, samples tested upto May , ,, samples tested on May , #StaySafe#UniteFightCorona@DBTIndiapic yQWLBsvubmdash #IndiaFightsCoronaMay , On Thursday, India recorded , deaths and , new Covid- infections over the last  hours.Scientists believe B may be more transmissible than the UK iant , which was first detected in Kent last year, and may be linked to the second wave in the country.Professor Robert Dingwall, who is a member of Nervtagndash an expert committee which advises the Government on the threat posed by new respiratory viruses ndash said that while B may be capable of becoming the dominant iant in the UK, the risk of a surge in deaths or hospital admissions remains low.He told the PA news agency: ldquoB seems to be slightly more transmissible and capable of outcompeting the B or Bto become the dominant iant in the UK.ldquoThe consequence of this would be a greater number of mild illnesses with little risk of a surge in hospitalisations or deaths.Will vaccines still work A fantastic day of vaccinations yesterday, with the team administering , vaccines across the UK ##Nearly two-thirds of adults have been vaccinated  over  in  adults have had two doses.When its your turn, come forward  get the jab. Every vaccination gives us hope. pic xaOmSJgDmdash Matt HancockMay , At present, there is no evidence the B iant is resistant to current vaccines.Although deemed to be more transmissible, it does not feature the EK mutation found in the South African iant of the virus, which could help the virus evade a personrsquos immune system and may affect how well coronavirus vaccines work.Prof Dingwall told PA: ldquoThis iant seems to be better managed by the vaccines than the South African iant so that vaccinated people have only a very low risk of infection that is likely to be mild.What other iants of concern have been identied in the UK NEW ndash wersquove entered into a partnership with @CureVacRNAto rapidly develop vaccines against new strainsWe must be prepared for all eventualities so weve placed an order for m doses,requiredI can also confirm the agreement will allow large-scale manufacturing in the UKmdash Kwasi KwartengFebruary , All viruses undergo small genetic changes as they make copies of themselves in the host.Most of these mutations are harmless but some can make the disease more infectious or threatening, and evade protection gained through infection or vaccination.PHE has designated the UK, South Africa and Braziliants as being ldquoof concern.Current vaccines have been designed for earlier versions of coronavirus, but scientists believe they should still work, but may be less effective.But experts are confident existing vaccines can be tweaked to better tackle emerging mutations.The UK Government has a deal with biopharmaceutical company CureVac to develop vaccines against future iants, and has pre-ordered  million doses..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Indian coronavirus iant: All you need to know as cases continue to rise

title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: plans-second-substation-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-lodged-council
story: The latest planning application, from Seagreen Wind Energy, shows a substation built on top of a former gasholder site stretching across paths which the firm admits may have to be erted.Seagreen sparked local concern when its initial consultation appeared to put the entire Greenhills in its proposed site.However, the plans now lodged with the council show the substation across the road from the former Cockenzie Power Stationrsquos main footprint on an old gasworks area now being used for a temporary car wash business.Acknowledging concerns raised by community councils over the loss of green space, Seagreenrsquos application says: ldquoAs far as possible, the proposed substationwill be sited to avoid any areas of habitat value. Where not possible, we confirm that any potential loss of woodland or scrub would be compensated for by post-construction landscape planting.And they added that any loss of existing footpaths was still to be discussedto agree how to mitigate it, adding: ldquoThis will likely involve a ersion to the existing footpath. If this is required, we will seek to minimise theof this ersion as far as possible.Seagreen currently has apoundbn offshore wind farm development under construction after it was granted exclusiverights for the Firth of Forth Zone of the UKrsquos Round  offshore wind farm development programme.Phase One within the zone includes the development of two offshore wind farms ndash Seagreen Alpha and Seagreen Bravo ndash located more than km from the Angus coastline.Work is already under way to bring the energy online at a number of sites, with Cockenzie the latest to be put forward.The former Cockenzie Power Station site was bought by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower after the stationrsquos iconic chimneys were demolished.It has been marketed by the local authority for projects, with a visionary masterplan setting out a wide range of employment, energy and recreational uses for the large -hectare site and surrounding area.To date, a substation which will bring energy onshore for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd is the only proposal given planning permissionfor the site.Seagreenrsquos proposals cover a nearby area of land outwith the power station footprint itself, including a beach car park next to it, where underground cables would be brought on land, under the main road and into the National Grid inshore.The proposal includes an onshore substation, underground electricity cables and ldquotemporary and permanent infrastructure to export electricity.

title: brunton-musselburgh-reopen-month
story: Audiences will be welcomed back to Venue  from May  as the team works to programme a range of theatre and concert screenings, with singing stars Michael Ball and Alfie Boe on screen on July  and co-founder of the band Fleetwood Mac, Mick Fleetwood and Friends, confirmed for September .Movie highlights get under way with Nomadland on May , Ammonite on June  and Minari on June .In line with Scottish Government regulations, The Brunton has a range of modications in place including signage, floor markings, sanitiser stations, enhanced cleaning schedules, face coverings, reduced capacity in the auditorium and advance booking only. Staff will be on hand to offer a warm welcome and answer any questions visitors have.The trust will continue to follow Scottish Government guidance and hopes to be able to resume live performances in the not-too-distant future as restrictions ease.Michael Stitt, chairman of The Brunton Theatre Trust, said: ldquoWe are delighted to finally be opening our doors again to welcome back our audiences from the local community and beyond.ldquoWorking with East Lothian Council, we have taken considerable steps to ensure a Covid-safe environment within our much-loved venue.ldquoCareful consideration will be given to the type of programming that we hope will be possible in the coming months, with the safety of our audiences and staff at the forefront of our artistic decision-making whilst always adhering to Scottish Government guidelines.Donations of any size are welcomed to help The Brunton continue to bring a programme of arts and entertainment to East Lothian and beyond.Financial contributions can be made via The Bruntonrsquos website thebruntonFull details of the cinema programme can be found on The Bruntonrsquos website.Further details about enhanced protocols and online ticket booking are also available at the venuersquos website.

title: burgh-primary-school-pupils-images-make-people-smile-bid-raise-money-playground-improvements
story: Pupils from  classes took part in a competition on the theme lsquoSomething That Makes You Smilersquo during the Easter holidays to produce photos for a school calendar which will be sold in aid of the playground project.Avril Campbell, reporter for the Musselburgh Courier, had the tough task of choosing winners on an anonymous basis and the results were announced at school assembly last Friday.The overall winner was lsquoSunset In The Harbourrsquo, by Romilly Upcraft, P, which will appear on the front page of the Burgh Primary  calendar.The other winners were: lsquoBarbies and My Friend Jackrsquo by Clara Bose, nursery lsquoThere Are Eggs Under There!rsquo by Anna Thomson, P lsquoDaffodil Picturersquo by Vinnie Dunn, P lsquoEtta In The Parkrsquo by Lily Doherty, P lsquoI Love Ice Creamrsquo by Caroline McDonough, P  lsquoPeek A Baarsquo by Ava Virlogeux, P lsquoBassie The Guillemotrsquo by Ophelia Carter, P  lsquoHeidirsquo by Lily Fisher, P lsquoSpring Bunniesrsquo by Erica Olds, P  lsquoBooks Hearts and Flowersrsquo by Anya Peet, P lsquoWinter Wonderlandrsquo by Angus Ross, P and lsquoThe Bridges rsquo by Lauren Hollingsworth, P.Avril said: ldquoIt was a very dficult decision as the standard was very high and the pupils were so imaginative with their subjects.S Luca of Musselburgh kindly donated chocolate treats for all the children who entered the competition.Jon Doyle, headteacher, said: ldquoOur all-weather pitch no longer has adequate goals, our adventure log-trail is intermittently closed due to disrepair and, vitally, surfaces and facilities need to be made safe and accessible for our wheelchair users.ldquoWe value the support of our parent council in working with us to make our playground area everything it can be for our children and community.The parent council has also organised other fundraising initiatives, including Easyfundraising, a school lottery and a local scavenger hunt.

title: mp-calls-a1-renamed-queens-highway-platinum-jubilee
story: Conservative MP Sir Edward Leigh wants the A renamed the Queenrsquos Highway.However, the idea has not met with universal favour throughout East Lothian, where the route stretches from Dunglass in the east to outside Musselburgh and the Edinburgh boundary.Sir Edward told the House of Commons the ldquobeautul Great North Road should be renamed after the Queen to celebrate her  years on the throne next year.Speaking during transport questions, he said: ldquoThe A, the Great North Road, is a beautul road linking Scotland and England ndash and I think, to honour the upcoming jubilee, we should rename it the Queenrsquos Highway why not ldquoBut it is not an entirely safe road. I have spent hundreds of hours on it there are many fatalities on it.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, felt there were more pressing matters than changing the -mile routersquos name.He said: ldquoWhat it needs is upgraded, not a new name.ldquoItrsquoll always be the A for most folk but having it fully dualled would be better.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the Dunbar and East Linton ward, was not in favour of the idea.He said: ldquoI think it is known as the A and donrsquot think it is appropriate to change it to a dferent name.ldquoIt should be known as the A trunk road and calling a road a particular name is not the right thing to do.ldquoThere are many other things that we could name that would be more appropriate for celebrating the Queenrsquos platinum jubilee.Councillor Tom Trotter, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, also felt there might be a more fitting gesture to mark the occasion than renaming the road.He said: ldquoI think the A suffices for me.ldquoIt has always been the A and always will be the A.ldquoIt is right that they mark the occasion in some manner but I am not sure this would be the way to do it.Preston Seton Gosford ward member councillor Lachlan Bruce felt the idea had merit.He said: ldquoThis idea is worthy of further consideration and it would be an appropriate way to mark Her Majestyrsquos platinum jubilee.ldquoHowever, what was of more importance in his contribution was the need to focus on signicantly upgrading the A.ldquoSir Edward was completely right about that and what we need to see is the A dualled all the way to the Border.An ldquoextra A turn-off was also required to serve the new town of Blindwells, he added.ldquoThat would take away the increased pressure on this vital route that everyone knows will build up there when people start to move into the new town, said Mr Bruce.While Tranent, Wallyford and Macmerry ward councillor Colin McGinn said: ldquoPeople are free to express their beliefs about recognising historic and important figures.ldquoAt this time, however, I feel the focus should be on getting the country on a road to recovery and allow the agencies involved to focus on that work. If there is an opinion that this is a good idea then it could be brought forward at a better time.Musselburgh councillor Stuart Currie agreed there would be other ideas worth considering.He said: ldquoThere are always lots of ideas that come from the House of Commons some make sense and some donrsquot.ldquoYou have to be careful of the costs of having to rename a trunk road going through Scotland to England it would be hugely costly.ldquoObviously, in terms of the trunk road network, as soon as you cross the Border it changes responsibility. I suspect he may have thought it only went to the Border and did not go any further.

title: petition-drawn-urging-dunbar-residents-back-plans-turn-assembly-rooms-flats
story: Alexander Williamsonrsquos attempts to see the vacant areas of the Dunbar Assembly Rooms, which dates back nearly  years, turned into four flats were rejected by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee in March.An appeal to Scottish Ministers is being drawn up, while a petition has been launched urging members of the public to back the proposal, which developers claim is ldquothe only course of action left.The petition, which developers hope will show public support for the plans, has already been signed by nearly  people.It notes that the building was bought at auction in , with permission in place for nine flats. But the planning consent lapsed in , which ldquostarted a long journey over many years and countless sleepless nights worrying for the safety of the residents living below.The petition notes: ldquoUnless we successfully lobby Scottish Ministers with our appeal, my parentsrsquo -year battle to regenerate this building could be lost.ldquoDunbarrsquos town centre regeneration will continue to be held back in favour of large out-of-town developments, risking the lives and livelihoods of local people, while we watch historic buildings deteriorate beyond repair.ldquoYou donrsquot need to look far in Dunbar to see the effects neglect has had on our history.ldquoThankfully, over the past  years, we have managed to maintain the structure of the Assembly Rooms, keeping a roof above the three basement flats below.ldquoThis has not come without expense and eventually the -year-old roof will need removednot replaced.ldquoThis building is older than some of Dunbarrsquos most iconic landmarks ndash nearly  years older than Abbey Church on High Street, for example.ldquoTo put this into perspective, the Assembly Rooms date back to , the same year as King George IV visited Scotland , three years after Queen Victoria was born, some  years before the Victoria Harbour in Dunbar, which was started in .ldquoPlease give us your support in order that we can challenge the decision of our local councillors, bring le back to this building and remove an eyesore from Church Street.The planning committee saw councillors split over whether the scheme, which was supported by the townrsquos community council, should go ahead.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire, who is the planning committee convenor, highlighted parking dficulties as being behind the reason for him opting to vote to refuse the application, despite planning officials recommending it be approved.The petition is at change.org p scottish-ministers-support-dunbar-s-assembly-rooms-planning-consent-appeal

title: plea-save-ground-floor-closed-haddington-pub-keep-business-use
story: Plans were revealed last month to transform the three-storey Gardeners Arms in the centre of Haddington.The historic venue, on the townrsquos Kilpair Street, dates back hundreds of years, with The Fraternity of Gardeners of East Lothian once based in the town.They purchased a property which contained an inn on the corner of Market Street.However, last orders may have been called at the pub, which has not been open for about three years.Flats would be created on each floor of the building under DSI Properties Ltdrsquos plans.Haddingtonrsquos community council did not object to the proposals but felt that the plans could be altered to keep the ground floor available for business use.The proposals suggest the insignia painted on the front of the building would be retained, something which was welcomed by the group.Paul Darling, one of the community councilrsquos planning liaison officers, said: ldquoIrsquom not averse to two flats but would quite like to see the bottom house kept for retail, personally.That view was backed by colleagues Pat Lemmon and Graham Samuel during the virtual meeting.The discussions came after it was highlighted that a number of businesses had moved into neighbouring High Street in recent months, despite the challenges brought by the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown restrictions.Chris McEwan, chairman of the community council, said: ldquoI quite agree with what is being said.ldquoWe have got businesses coming into the town and there have been three opening in recent months, even during the year we have had.ldquoKeeping another retail opportunity there, especially in that part of town, is a good idea.Community councils are given the opportunity to provide their views on any planning application.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department aims to make a decision on the application by the end of the month.The Haddington group agreed to write to East Lothian Council about the proposals, with community councillor John Hamilton suggesting it was ldquoa preference rather than an insistence that the business unit on the ground floor remain in place.A supporting statement included within the planning application highlights the dficulties facing pubs and the lack of apparent interest in someone taking over the Gardeners.It reads: ldquoThe property was sold recently to our client.ldquoIt had ceased to operate as a public house almost three years ago and had been marketed for sale without interest.ldquoThe climate in that market has not been good for some time and will become even more dficult following the current Covid outbreakand the economic fallout from this.ldquoIt is clear that an alternative use for the property needs to be foundit is not to fall into disrepair.ldquoWith this in mind, our clients opted for residential use.ldquoMore and more properties in town and city centres are being given up to residential use in an attempt to bring le back to them and help sustain existing business outlets which have managed to keep trading.

title: artists-selected-bring-special-new-hare-trail-life-families-can-watch-action
story: Leuchie House respite centre, based just outside the town, is gearing up and working hard to launch The Big Hare Trail on July , which is being held in celebration of its -year anniversary as an independent charity.The  giant hares will be placed around North Berwick for  weeks in a free family-friendly trail.More than  entries were submitted to the public art event.And now all of the artists who will prime, paint, adorn and embellish the  hare sculptures have been selected.Each of the fibreglass sculptures has been sponsored by a business and will be inidually decorated in a unique style by the selected artists.Each artist has received a pound commission and the opportunity to work alongside a commercial sponsor.Hares were chosen as one of the most popular and high-profile animals native to East Lothian.Already, artist Emily Hogarth has been announced as an ambassador for the trail.She is being joined by Julia Zeller-Jacques, who runs North Berwick High Street shop Rock  Bird Rachel Marshall of Bonzo Art, whose work can be found in WhyNot  in the town Lorraine Miller, who owns Between the Woods and Sea, a North-Berwick based handmade ceramic and wire sculptures business award-winning North Berwick-based artist Georgina Bown Catherine Rayner, an award-winning author and illustrator who moved from Yorkshire to Edinburgh Chris Rutterford, one of Scotlandrsquos top mural artists, based in Edinburgh Chrisrsquos partner Lubi Lykan Rosie Watson, a Duncan of Jordanstone College of Art and Design graduate illustration graduate Abbie Herriot and local artist Ali Blevins.Lana Bambridge, head of fundraising at Leuchie House, said that the charityrsquos team and sponsors had their work cut out picking the final designs.She said: ldquoWe were absolutely delighted with the response to our callout to artists.ldquoThe calibre of artists was very high, with design entries from all over the UK, but it made the selection process much harder.ldquoMany artists chose an East Lothian-based theme, while others gave due consideration to the work and cause of the charity.ldquoWhat made the designs more impressive were the compelling stories behind the artistsrsquo inspiration. In the end, we have managed to find a balance of styles, themes and unique characteristics. We are keen to showcase the artistic culture that embodies East Lothian and are delighted to have so many local artists represented.All of the hares are currently in production at a lodge-turned-artistsrsquo hub at spa and health club Whitekirk Hill, where they will complete their work.Families are being encouraged to pop along for a sneak peak of the artists at work, with just a matter of weeks to bring their designs to le before they are transported to their designated locations.In a fun addition, there are even lsquopeep holesrsquo for visitors to utilise!Mark Bevan, Leuchie House CEO, said the campaign had created a ldquoreal buzz.He added: ldquoWe wanted to celebrate Leuchiersquos th anniversary in a way that could involve and benefit the community as a whole, by providing a free family-friendly event to inspire young minds and showcase East Lothianrsquos vibrant culture.Each sculpture will eventually be auctioned to raise funds for Leuchie House.

title: vet-column-ball-swallowing-loki-proves-dog-mischief
story: Do remember that, for many pups, le has been unusual in that they were unable to socialise with other dogs and humans, so it may well be a stressful time for them.We all assume our pets are happy because we care for them and keep them healthy, but often little changes in the home environment which we take for granted can be a major change for your pet, resulting in some degree of stress.If you do not spot this quickly, behavioural changes can occur which can take a long time to correct. Not all animals are the same some cats and dogs enjoy noise and excitement, but to others this would be very stressful.Others like peace and quiet ndash but to some, being left quiet and alone is stressful.I think most of us are aware that sudden, unusual noises can frighten pets for example, thunderstorms and fireworks. These are sounds which are strange to your pet and can result in a great deal of stress.In a recent survey carried out by the PDSA,  per cent of owners said their pet was scared of fireworks. The main signs the owners reported were cowering and hiding, trembling and shaking, disinterest in food and barking.Pets left alone either at home or in a cattery or kennel, which are unusual occurrences, can result in severe stress, as the pet feels abandoned by their family.Bringing in a new pet or moving home can also feel terrying for a pet which is used to constancy. Sometimes the dynamics of the pets within a home can change and one or more pet can feel threatened.At Dunedin Vets, at the beginning of lockdown, we saw many problems, especially with cats who were not used to their owners being at home all the time.Cats are notoriously sensitive to change. They may hide their stress but it can manest in other ways.This can include bladder problems and over-grooming and itching.Please contact your vet for adviceyou feel your pet requires some help to overcome their stress-related problems.It is wonderful to be out and about in the spring sunshine, albeit it is a bit chilly at the moment.Remember, there are a few hazards to avoid when walking your dog.Do not throw sticks for them to catch or retrieve. These can cause terrible injuriesthe dog runs onto them and injuries occur in their mouth or, as I have seen, penetrate their skin and damage structures in their necks.Last month, we mentioned the collie dog who was chasing his ball and accidentally swallowed it.Recently, our senior veterinary nurse Nicole saw a young couple rush to the front door of our Tranent surgery, carrying their dog. The owners were obviously very distressed, so Nicole spoke with them and discovered that they were sure Loki, their three-year-old cockapoo, had tried to swallow the bouncy ball toy he had been playing with.Mrs Pamela Masson explained it was a hard rubber ball with rubber spikes on it.Nicole could hear Loki making strange noises when breathing she checked he was able to breathe and called the vet to examine Loki. Gently opening his mouth, they could just glimpse something blue at the back of his mouth.Nicole had previously been involved in dealing with a dog which had choked on a ball. She knew this dog was somehow managing to breathe, unlike the previous one she had dealt with, which was unable to breathe and had been rapidly turning blue.She reassured the owners and admitted Loki for treatment to extract the ball. As choking animals are very distressed, they are likely to panic and bite, although Loki was remaining remarkably calm. The team prepared short-acting intravenous anaesthetic and several pairs of dferent-sized forceps to help extract the ball. Once a catheter was placed in Lokirsquos leg vein, everything had to be performed rapidly as soon as the anaesthetic injection was administered, to prevent the ball falling further into Lokirsquos larynx or dropping into the oesophagus. With Nicole supporting his head and a light being shone into the mouth, the blue spiky ball was seen. Grasping it with forceps, and with some tension and rotation, the vet extracted the offending ball from Lokirsquos throat.The ball had a central hole, or tunnel, running through it. This was the reason Loki was able to breathe, albeit in a laboured, noisy fashion.The ball had lodged with its central tunnel in line with Lokirsquos mouth and larynx. The rubber spikes caused a bit of damage to the soft areas around his larynx, but these would soon heal.
